Also requires #1536 for test passing

### Possible Drawbacks 

A lot of code duplication, feel free to propose ideas for fixes

### Usage Examples or Tests

Added `python_client_test` and java one, as previously in `java_builders_test`

### Alternate Designs

SWIG can accept pair `char*, size_t` and remain using native stuff (like byte[] in java), although it's still requires non-trivial (e.g memory management) for return types. So for being consistent interface use std::vector both for return value and input ones

1. Renamed and rearranged build parameters in Jenkinsfile
  - `iroha` - means that code will be built on `x86_64` agent. Plus additional platforms could be chosen
    - `armv7_linux`
    - `armv8_linux`
    - `x86_64_macos`
  - `bindings`:
    - `x86_64_linux`
    - `x86_64_win`

2. Fixed `nightly` build notifications. Now they've been sent to `sorabot`'s email
3. Fixed overall pipeline time limit to 3 hours. Currently, rare Jenkins build jobs could hang forever until build is manually cancelled.
4. Fix `nightly` build pipeline: added `expressions` for some CI stages to simplify parameter setup for scheduled job

### Benefits

Fixes #1519

title: Fix issue with synchronization after time gap
body:
### Description of the Change

This pr introduces 3 main prerequisite fixes:
- Reordering of *Validator ctor parameters, so that `FieldValidator` is the first one
- Reusing existing `FieldValidator` in SignableModelValidator
- `FieldValidator` can now has time provider other than `iroha::time::now`

And the main fix is for BlockValidator. It now performs time validation based on the block field, so it's possible to synchronize blocks after a time gap passed.

### Benefits

Probably faster `SignableModelValidator`, since it don't need to allocate field validator
Peers can synchronize "expired" (in terms of current time) blocks from the network

### Possible Drawbacks 

`BlockValidator` is allocated on each `BlockLoaderImpl::retrieveBlock` (should it be a class field?)
`BlockLoaderImpl` cannot be parametrized with `BlockValidator` (though it wasn't used)

### Usage Examples or Tests

Test hasn't been added, but the existing one was modified and can verify the behavior:
`test_bin/block_validator_test`

title: Add Permissions Docs Compiler
body:
<!-- You will not see HTML commented line in Pull Request body -->
<!-- Optional sections may be omitted. Just remove them or write None -->

<!-- ### Requirements -->
<!-- * Filling out the template is required. Any pull request that does not include enough information to be reviewed in a timely manner may be closed at the maintainers' discretion. -->

<!-- * Critical and blocker issues reported by Sorabot must be fixed. -->
<!-- * Branch must be rebased onto base branch (https://soramitsu.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/IS/pages/11173889/Rebase+and+merge+guide). -->


### Description of the Change

The change introduces a way to compile docs permissions page automatically.
Now, `permissions.rst` should NOT be modified manually.

The compiler uses `csv` file as a source of permissions' description, notable information, and examples description.
The compiler automatically makes references to the glossary for the terms occurred in permissions' descriptions (like wiki engine). The same term within a single description would not be transformed to a reference more than once.
The compiler makes a reference to commands that are related to corresponding permissions.
The compiler automatically includes listings of python examples.


<!-- We must be able to understand the design of your change from this description. If we can't get a good idea of what the code will be doing from the description here, the pull request may be closed at the maintainers' discretion. -->
<!-- Keep in mind that the maintainer reviewing this PR may not be familiar with or have worked with the code here recently, so please walk us through the concepts. -->

### Benefits

It is easier to maintain the long list of permissions in any table/sheet editor than edit very long `rst` source file.

Permissions page format can be easily changed via applying changes to compiler script.

<!-- What benefits will be realized by the code change? -->

### Possible Drawbacks 

Potentially no beautiful architecture inside compiler scripts. It may become a subject of refactoring later on.

<!-- What are the possible side-effects or negative impacts of the code change? -->
<!-- If no drawbacks, explicitly mention this (write None) -->

### Usage Examples or Tests

Please check already compiled page here https://html-drqyakiigy.now.sh/maintenance/permissions
(Navigation menu may be broken, most likely due to internal url rewrite rules of now.sh)

The other way is to compile docs locally - please check `docs/README.md` and issue `make permissions` before `make html`.

title: Remove hasAccountGrantablePermissions in qry exec
body:
### Description of the Change

For some reason Queries are checked against Grantable permissions (Grantable are only for commands). This pr removes redundant code (checking in execution, checking in EXPECT_CALL's, test for grantable perms) also `permissions::permissionOf` removal is there 

### Benefits

The lesser useless code the happier people are

### Possible Drawbacks 

None?

title: Migrate to postgres bitstring perms
body:
### Description of the Change

At WSV there've been used enum types similar to SM ones. It's probably inefficient and error prone (code hard to read and permissions need to be maintained).
This PR introduces behavior based on postgres bitstrings: conversion is built-in and querying is simply perfromed via boolean operations.

### Benefits

Efficiency, no need in postgres types maintaining, cleaner code, a bit better interface for PermissionSet

### Possible Drawbacks

SQL queries become more complicated :(

title: Cache CLI input values
body:
<!-- You will not see HTML commented line in Pull Request body -->
<!-- Optional sections may be omitted. Just remove them or write None -->

<!-- ### Requirements -->
<!-- * Filling out the template is required. Any pull request that does not include enough information to be reviewed in a timely manner may be closed at the maintainers' discretion. -->
<!-- * All new code must have code coverage above 70% (https://docs.codecov.io/docs/about-code-coverage). -->
<!-- * CircleCI builds must be passed. -->
<!-- * Critical and blocker issues reported by Sorabot must be fixed. -->
<!-- * Branch must be rebased onto base branch (https://soramitsu.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/IS/pages/11173889/Rebase+and+merge+guide). -->


### Description of the Change

Cache CLI input values to make it more convenient (#827).

There are two use cases. 

1. Make is possible to use default values provided during creation of a `iroha_cli::interactive::ParamsMap` - If a default value is provided (e.g. default host/port), that will be used when the user input is empty.
2. Cache any user inputs - When an input is captured for a parameter, that value is cached and displayed on the input prompt for that parameter. If the user input is empty, cache value will be used.

### Benefits

Get rid of annoying repeated host/port entries when attempting to send requests to Iroha (among other inputs) and make the CLI less frustrating to use.

### Possible Drawbacks 

There's no option to remove a cached value other than replacing it with a new value. However, the CLI doesn't allow empty inputs so this shouldn't be a problem.

### Usage Examples or Tests

#### Scenario 1 - Using default values

There's no user input for `Peer port (50051)`, default is used (prompt displays the default values).
```
$ ../build/bin/iroha-cli -account_name admin@test

Choose what to do:
1. New transaction (tx)
2. New query (qry)
3. New transaction status request (st)

2. Get Account's Asset Transactions (get_acc_ast_tx)
3. Get Account's Signatories (get_acc_sign)
4. Get Account's Assets (get_acc_ast)
5. Get all current roles in the system (get_roles)
6. Get information about asset (get_ast_info)
7. Get Account's Transactions (get_acc_tx)
8. Get Transactions by transactions' hashes (get_tx)
9. Get all permissions related to role (get_role_perm)
0. Back (b)
> : 7
Requested account Id: admin@test
Query is formed. Choose what to do:
1. Send to Iroha peer (send)
2. Save as json file (save)
0. Back (b)
> : 1
Peer address (0.0.0.0): localhost
Peer port (50051):

[2018-06-22 22:42:44.265988000][th:5963568][info] QueryResponseHandler -Hash- ed98fb922acad35d9262d56115daba6b092722f60523a9e3e03e642cc2364fd3

[2018-06-22 22:42:44.267753000][th:5963568][info] QueryResponseHandler  TransferAsset: [src_account_id=admin@test, dest_account_id=test@test, asset_id=coolcoin#test, description=, amount=Amount: [intValue=10050, precision=2, ], ]
```

#### Scenario 2 - Using cached values

There aren't any user inputs for `Requested account Id (admin@test)`, `Peer address (localhost)` and `Peer port (50051) `, cached valued are used. Note the prompt displays the cached values.

title: Hyperledger Iroha v1.0.0_beta-3
body:
In this release following changes were made:

## Experimental multi-signature transactions support

This is one of the most important features so far, since it allows integrators of Iroha to customise validation logic and may help people who want to have smart-contracts support. Let me tell you more:

As per definition of [multi signature account](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multisignature) on wikipedia, it is a type of account, which has a special condition, associated with the account: it is related to a number of cryptographic signatures required to issue valid transactions from the account, or "quorum". Quorum is a requirement to have M of N signatures, attached to transaction, where N is a total number of public keys associated with the account.

It helps to build following logic:
- in order to form a valid transaction a user of Iroha has to apply several keys distributed across several people or devices to her transactions
- in order to form a valid transaction a user of a service with Iroha may send her transactions to a service, which validates some custom logic (amount of transferred assets, special fields, whatever) and this service can add a signature to transaction if it passed custom validation 

What is different in Iroha, compared to other services, is that a user is able to send transactions to peer network which don't have all required signatures, "half-baked". Iroha puts them in a temporary storage and distributes across the network. In the end, when Iroha peer network has received enough "half-baked" transactions (quorum condition is valid) such transaction is sent to Iroha validation and is written in the ledger in case of successful validation. 

If you are curious — check code in https://github.com/hyperledger/iroha/pull/1260. Docs are going to be available gradually in our [documentation website](https://iroha.readthedocs.io). 

## Block streaming

This would allow people to create services around Iroha that can listen to events happening on the chain — like specific transactions. In the future, it would allow us to implement block explorer functionality as well. 

## Python and Java Bindings for Windows platform

Check it in https://github.com/hyperledger/iroha/pull/1335 and at [artifact.soramitsu.co.jp](http://artifact.soramitsu.co.jp) website

## Other features 
- All assets now are returned instead of a single asset in GetAccountAssets (https://github.com/hyperledger/iroha/pull/1402)
- Permissions are now implemented as enums instead of strings (https://github.com/hyperledger/iroha/pull/1444, https://github.com/hyperledger/iroha/pull/1434, https://github.com/hyperledger/iroha/pull/1407, https://github.com/hyperledger/iroha/pull/1408, https://github.com/hyperledger/iroha/pull/1384)
- Ability to specify postgres database name on irohad startup 
- Improved stateless validation for precision (https://github.com/hyperledger/iroha/pull/1370)
- Reduced CPU usage caused by compilation of regexes (https://github.com/hyperledger/iroha/pull/1345)
- Protobuf schema changes causes automatic generation of cpp files on build (https://github.com/hyperledger/iroha/pull/1441)
- Hash can now be created from hex string (https://github.com/hyperledger/iroha/pull/1475)
- Overwriting existing genesis block requires approval on Irohad start (thanks to @ZeekHuge) (https://github.com/hyperledger/iroha/pull/1300)
- CLI now supports GetAccountAssetTransactions command (https://github.com/hyperledger/iroha/pull/1323)
- Significant compilation time improvements for irohad (https://github.com/hyperledger/iroha/pull/1424, https://github.com/hyperledger/iroha/pull/1414)

## Fixes
- Fixed block query race condition which prevented making queries in a quick succession (https://github.com/hyperledger/iroha/pull/1396)
- Fixed a bug which prevented synchronization between a newly added peer and the network (https://github.com/hyperledger/iroha/pull/1390)
- Transfer asset now correctly handles mismatch between command's and asset's precision(https://github.com/hyperledger/iroha/pull/1470)
- SetAccountDetail command can be executed on itself without any permissions (https://github.com/hyperledger/iroha/pull/1452)
- If account name is not specified CLI will not issue a message about keypair generation (https://github.com/hyperledger/iroha/pull/1455)
- fromPrivateKey now throws exception which can be caught (no more runtime errors!) (https://github.com/hyperledger/iroha/pull/1429)
- Simulator now retrieves block height from storage, rather than current proposal (https://github.com/hyperledger/iroha/pull/1360)
- When transaction is finalized before subscription, correct status is returned (https://github.com/hyperledger/iroha/commit/dc6b0a45af4b6ca6b2f8f4a1da0a8ae2fd8c0e72)
- Java bindings are generated in correct packages (https://github.com/hyperledger/iroha/pull/1382)

## Docs
- [Permissions documentation](https://iroha.readthedocs.io/en/latest/maintenance/permissions.html)
- [Transaction Statuses](http://iroha.readthedocs.io/en/latest/core_concepts/glossary.html#transaction-statuses)
- [Entity-Relationship model](http://iroha.readthedocs.io/en/latest/core_concepts/er_model.html)

## CI Improvements
- MacOS pipeline has --output-on-failure flag turned on by default (https://github.com/hyperledger/iroha/pull/1425)
- Added MSVC build pipeline for shared model (https://github.com/hyperledger/iroha/pull/1358)

### Description of the Change

The PR introduces Binary Testing Framework.
BTF allows performing stateful validation for transactions and queries built using client libraries. 
For now, only Python is supported. Java support will be added later on.

This PR comes with python scripts that cover all the set of Iroha permissions.

<!-- We must be able to understand the design of your change from this description. If we can't get a good idea of what the code will be doing from the description here, the pull request may be closed at the maintainers' discretion. -->

### Benefits

Now here is the tool for stateful validation of transactions and queries created via client libraries.

Also, here is a set of python examples that shows how to use Iroha permissions model. (Scripts' listings will be included into "permissions" page at ReadTheDocs).

<!-- What benefits will be realized by the code change? -->

### Usage Examples or Tests

```
cmake -H. -Bbuild -DSWIG_PYTHON=ON
cmake --build build --target binary_test
cd build
ctest -R binary
```

<!-- Point reviewers to the test, code example or documentation which shows usage example of this feature -->

### Possible Improvements

The existing set of python example scripts can be extended with tests which validate the correctness of resulting state after applying transactions to Iroha (that approach was not the point of current tests set).

Such improvement will require changes in the implementation of Python and Java launchers.

title: Add implementation of on_demand ordering service
body:
### Description of the Change
Add implementation of ordering service that managed by proposals by request.
Method of the work:
Each round we:
 * pack new proposal into unordered_map for sharing in the network;
 * erase old proposals;
 * collect transactions in the concurrent queue for further packing to the proposal in a next round.

Execution model:
Each network method may be called from concurrently, updates of invariant are covered by a write lock, rest by a read lock. `OnTransactions` may be called in different threads simultaneously.

Rounds:
We form proposal round as a pair [BlockRound, RejectRound], where the BlockRound is a number of blocks in the ledger + 1, RejectRound is a number of rejects + 1.
For example, first round in the network will be [2, 1].


### Benefits

One small step to BFT Iroha

### Possible Drawbacks 
The implementation doesn't contain tests.

### Reviewers notes

Pls, keep focusing on the following issues:
* redundant copies, especially, in the proposal generation
* race conditions
* imperative style - I hope, that you may suggest a more elegant solution.

title: Fix TransferAsset strange behavior
body:
### Description of the Change

Transfering asset with non-zero precision causes writing to WSV amount without precision and that basically lead to the strange things.

Particularly amount at [this line](https://github.com/hyperledger/iroha/pull/1470/files#diff-61f63c72eb4f7dc6082d4c9a2a4f8b5cL451) isn't properly set because it's not adjusted to the proper precision. Basically interested line is [this](https://github.com/hyperledger/iroha/pull/1470/files#diff-61f63c72eb4f7dc6082d4c9a2a4f8b5cL425) but it contains result, so there's no easy fix, so that's why the PR contains refactorings

### Benefits

Plus one test and minus one bug.
Also code for execution of TransferAsset was flattened (thus i believe simpler to read)

### Possible Drawbacks 

None

### Usage Examples or Tests *[optional]*

`make transfer_asset_test && test_bin/transfer_asset_test`

title: Python bindings (win, linux, mac)
body:
### Description of the Change

This PR allows make python wheels distributable packages on Windows, Linux and Mac OS from automaticaly generated artifacts

### Benefits

Simple and faster distribution of python packages

### Possible Drawbacks 

* Python version - 3.5.5 and 2.7.15
* Only for x86_64 systems

- [x] Versioning (for wheels) is needed
- [x] Documentation for PyPI package
- [x] Different repositories for release/dev/nightly builds
- [x] Change SWIG generation for .py files
- [x] Upload only Release wheels to artifact server
- [x] Test import module on "clean" OS  

### About Nexus
https://nexus.soramitsu.co.jp/ - our new PyPI, Maven, artifacts server

https://nexus.soramitsu.co.jp/repository/pypi-develop/ - developer wheels
https://nexus.soramitsu.co.jp/repository/pypi-release/ - release wheels
https://nexus.soramitsu.co.jp/repository/pypi-develop-nightly/ - develop nightly wheels

#### Example
```
pip install -i https://nexus.soramitsu.co.jp/repository/pypi-{develop,release,develop-nightly}/ iroha-hl
```

#### Add to ~/.pypirc
```
[distutils]
index-servers=
    pypi-develop
    pypi-release
    pypi-develop-nightly
   
[pypi-develop]
repository: https://nexus.soramitsu.co.jp/repository/pypi-develop/
[pypi-release]
repository: https://nexus.soramitsu.co.jp/repository/pypi-release/
[pypi-dev-nightly]
repository: https://nexus.soramitsu.co.jp/repository/pypi-develop-nightly/

pip install -r pypi-develop iroha-hl
```
Reference PR: #1454

title: Prepare YAC for BFT OS and gossip vote propagation
body:
<!-- You will not see HTML commented line in Pull Request body -->
<!-- Optional sections may be omitted. Just remove them or write None -->

<!-- ### Requirements -->
<!-- * Filling out the template is required. Any pull request that does not include enough information to be reviewed in a timely manner may be closed at the maintainers' discretion. -->
<!-- * All new code must have code coverage above 70% (https://docs.codecov.io/docs/about-code-coverage). -->
<!-- * CircleCI builds must be passed. -->
<!-- * Critical and blocker issues reported by Sorabot must be fixed. -->
<!-- * Branch must be rebased onto base branch (https://soramitsu.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/IS/pages/11173889/Rebase+and+merge+guide). -->


### Description of the Change
Change YAC transport and interfaces:
 - Transport Commit and Reject messages replaced with State message
 - Single endpoint used to send state
 - Single methods to process state instead of 3 methods for vote, commit, and reject in YAC related classes
 - YAC interface returns outcome -- commit or reject, so it can be appropriately handled by consensus users
 - Commit/reject is passed to YAC subscribers only after receiving an appropriate message instead of a single vote [IR-1401](https://soramitsu.atlassian.net/browse/IR-1401)
<!-- We must be able to understand the design of your change from this description. If we can't get a good idea of what the code will be doing from the description here, the pull request may be closed at the maintainers' discretion. -->
<!-- Keep in mind that the maintainer reviewing this PR may not be familiar with or have worked with the code here recently, so please walk us through the concepts. -->

### Benefits
 - Unified network interface which can be used by multiple propagation strategies like multicast or gossip
 - Simplified logic in transport, storage, crypto verifier, message handlers
<!-- What benefits will be realized by the code change? -->

### Possible Drawbacks 
 - More complex logic in YAC message handler -- probably it is possible to move it to separate class
<!-- What are the possible side-effects or negative impacts of the code change? -->
<!-- If no drawbacks, explicitly mention this (write None) -->

### Note to reviewers
Since the pull request affects ~22~34 files, it may be difficult to review as a single change/pull request.
Each commit in this branch passes the tests, so it can be safely separated into multiple pull requests by request of reviewers.
Also you can consider reviewing separate commits, as they localize the changes to different entities, such as network notifications, crypto provider, storage, and YAC itself.

title: Use new perms in Ametsuchi
body:
### Description of the Change

Ametsuchi uses enum-based permissions. WSV scheme is now unisng internal enum types. 

### Benefits

One more step toward legacy model removal.
Types introduction discovered that conversion between types was a bit messy, e.g check out that line:
https://github.com/hyperledger/iroha/blob/33f80ae9734251a92e9852fd31cb2ed309699fe4/irohad/execution/impl/query_execution.cpp#L73

Operations for PermissionSet are more efficient:
https://github.com/hyperledger/iroha/blob/33f80ae9734251a92e9852fd31cb2ed309699fe4/irohad/execution/impl/common_executor.cpp#L42
https://github.com/hyperledger/iroha/blob/33f80ae9734251a92e9852fd31cb2ed309699fe4/irohad/execution/impl/command_executor.cpp#L718

### Possible Drawbacks 

Additional string allocations in WSV (similar below):
https://github.com/hyperledger/iroha/blob/33f80ae9734251a92e9852fd31cb2ed309699fe4/irohad/ametsuchi/impl/postgres_wsv_command.cpp#L90

Checking of number of permissions in the set can be messy and error prone:
https://github.com/hyperledger/iroha/blob/33f80ae9734251a92e9852fd31cb2ed309699fe4/test/module/irohad/ametsuchi/wsv_query_command_test.cpp#L139

Type creation is barely readable :(
https://github.com/hyperledger/iroha/blob/33f80ae9734251a92e9852fd31cb2ed309699fe4/irohad/ametsuchi/impl/storage_impl.cpp#L306-L322

That might be not necessary (todo: check):
https://github.com/hyperledger/iroha/blob/33f80ae9734251a92e9852fd31cb2ed309699fe4/irohad/ametsuchi/impl/storage_impl.cpp#L148-L150

### Alternate Designs

IMO postgres should use bitstring (for enums) and know nothing about enum strcture (thus less pain with migrations)

<!-- * Branch must be rebased onto base branch (https://soramitsu.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/IS/pages/11173889/Rebase+and+merge+guide). -->

[IR-1223](https://soramitsu.atlassian.net/browse/IR-1223)

### Description of the Change

Previously, there was no possibility for client code to catch exceptions thrown by ModelCrypto::fromPrivateKey method, so type of exception was changed to std::invalid_argument.
Also, a check for equality between private_key argument's length and 64 was added with related exception throw in case of failure.
Lastly, a couple of new tests were written to test new functionality. 
Overall, this is remake of [old pull request](https://github.com/hyperledger/iroha/pull/1254), which was not fixed and merged.

### Benefits

The exception can now be caught by client's code

### Possible Drawbacks 

None

<!-- * Branch must be rebased onto base branch (https://soramitsu.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/IS/pages/11173889/Rebase+and+merge+guide). -->


### Description of the Change
`withRegistry` wrapper used in `release-build.groovy` file prevented from executing experimental Docker commands. Namely, `docker manifest` that is used to manage manifest files on Docker hub. My suggestion is that this wrapper somehow fiddles with the system environment and shoves its own `config.json` without experimental features enabled.
This wrapper was redundant anyway as we use `withCredentials` to passthrough login and password for Docker hub.

title: Refactor/shared model compile time query responses
body:
### Description of the Change

Moved definitions of methods, constructors and some local variables of queries responses in interfaces and backend protobuf into separate .cpp files from headers. It reduced build time of Iroha (target irohad) - the process was launched via ```make -j3 irohad```:
Before: ```user 1344.03s system 103.16s```. Total 1 447,19s
After: ```user 1290.79s, system 100.76s```. Total 1 391,55s

### Benefits

The build time was reduced by 4.00%

### Possible Drawbacks 

More files to maintain

body:

<!-- * Branch must be rebased onto base branch (https://soramitsu.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/IS/pages/11173889/Rebase+and+merge+guide). -->


### Description of the Change
- Getting started guide did not reflect changes required to run Iroha with Postgres. `config.sample` file from `example` directory uses `localhost` as a Postgres host Iroha should connect to. It actually should connect to the host matching Postgres container name.
- Removed block storage creation step as Docker creates it automatically on container start up.
- The other section suggested to override entrypoint and run Iroha manually. Rewrite it so Iroha uses entrypoint defined on Docker image creation. Supplement `docker run` command with `KEY` environment variable. That is to instruct Iroha container using keys from `example` directory.
<!-- We must be able to understand the design of your change from this description. If we can't get a good idea of what the code will be doing from the description here, the pull request may be closed at the maintainers' discretion. -->

<!-- * Branch must be rebased onto base branch (https://soramitsu.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/IS/pages/11173889/Rebase+and+merge+guide). -->


### Description of the Change

Before BlockVariant was implemented via `using BlockVariantType=boost::variant<Block, EmptyBlock>`. This is not convenient in irohad because it forces to use visitors every time when it is needed to access BlockVariant's fields

Now it is a class which gives more convenient access to the fields in stored type

### Benefits

More convenient field access for BlockVariant

### Possible Drawbacks 

Multiple inheritance from boost::variant (to allow instantiation with either Block or EmptyBlock) and AbstractBlock (to guarantee AbstractBlocks interface)

None

title: New CI pipeline
body:
## Description of the Change

This PR is created to finally make our CI satisfy proposed requirements by our developers team.
### 1 Major changes
#### 1.1 Pipeline stages
Since now, the Pipeline consists of 6 stages. You can see the ascii-art pipeline version in the `Jenkinsfile`

| Stage | Description |
|:--:|:---|
| Pre-build | Cancels previous build job (except if current branch is `develop`) |
| Build | Build step for all platforms (currently `ARMv7`, `ARMv8`, `x86_64`, `MacOS` are present) |
| Pre-coverage | Launch coverage target before running tests |
| Tests | Run required tests for specified platforms |
| Post-Coverage | Run coverage after tests step |
| Build rest | Build (if required): 1) documentation 2) bindings 3) release version of `iroha` |

This division is made to improve visibility of the CI build process.
Stage separation is implemented in Jenkinsfile. All stage methods are implemented in `.jenkinsci/debug-build.groovy`, `.jenkinsci/release-build.groovy`, `.jenkinsci/mac-debug-build.groovy`, `.jenkinsci/mac-release-build.groovy` (note that `MacOS` build goes on the physical machine, not in the docker container, that's why there's another file for `MacOS` platform)

#### 1.2 On-demand Jenkins agents

Since now `x86_64` agents are moved to AWS EC2. There are 4 different labels added to the pipeline (note that it could be easily modified in Jenkins configuration):
- `x86_64_aws_build` -- general purpose instance with 8 CPU, 32 Gb RAM (x86_64 builds in 8 threads)
- `x86_64_aws_test` -- general purpose instance with 1 CPU, 2 Gb RAM for running tests
- `x86_64_aws_cov` -- general purpose instance with 1 CPU, 2 Gb RAM for running coverage
- `x86_64_aws_sonar` -- general purpose instance with 1 CPU, 2 Gb RAM for running `sonarscanner`

Now, the amount of `x86_64` agents will be float, as their amount is managed by Jenkins.

> *Note:* With migration to Amazon AWS EC2 on-demand agents the logic of some methods has been changed. The text below describes this change.

**On-demand agent start-up process**
Before freshly created and launched new AWS instance becomes the Jenkins agent, init script is executed. It mounts 4 folders via NFS share (AWS EFS - Amazon Elastic Filesystem).
- Jenkins workspace (`/var/jenkins`)
- `cmake` build cache (`/opt/.ccache`)
- `cmake` release build cache (`/opt/.ccache-release`)
- docker images storage (`/tmp/docker`)

**On-demand agent pipeline lifecycle**
In case the build occures on the `x86_64*` agent, the created docker image (stage `Build`) is saved to AWS EFS (Amazon Elastic Filesystem) using `docker save -o` command with file name `/tmp/docker/<branch_name_sha1>`. (see file `.jenkinsci/docker-pull-or-build.groovy`, method `dockerPullOrUpdate()`). When going to the next stage, new `x86_64*` agent is created, docker image is loaded from the file `/tmp/docker/<branch_name_sha1>` using `docker load` command.

After the stage finishes, the docker container is stopped and removed, results are saved to the Jenkins workspace (and to the AWS EFS respectively), thus, none of the data is lost.

#### 1.3 Merge availability

To make CI available to perform automatic merge process the list of features should be implemented: 
- check merge requirements compliance
- merge strategy

Merge requirements set in `hyperledger/iroha` repository:
- at least 2 `APPROVED` reviews
- CI checks are passed (`armv7`, `armv8` are turned off in case of `MergePR` is chosen)
- all commits are `sign-off`

Merge strategy regarding the branches:
- `trunk` + `develop` -- `squash & merge`
- `master` -- merge

All checks are made using Github API. To see the implementation, go to `.jenkinsci/github-api.groovy` file.

> To merge, developer should go to ```Jenkins -> iroha -> iroha-hyperledger -> Pull Requests -> PR # -> Build with Parameters``` and set checkpoint for Merge_PR.

#### 1.4 CI notifications

Build result notifications were added. Table below describes the notification scenario:

|Scenario|Behavior|
|:--:|:--|
| Branch commit|sends e-mail to git commit author|
| Open or Commit Pull Request | posts comment with PR reviewers mention on the PR page |
| Merge to `trunk` | sends e-mail to git commit author |
| Merge to `develop` | sends e-mail to git commit author + Andrei + Fyodor |
| Merge to `master` | sends e-mail to iroha-maintainers team |

Notification e-mail contains compressed log in attachmens + build status.
see `.jenkinsci/notifications.groovy`,`Jenkinsfile` (cleanup post-step at the end of the file)

#### 1.5 Tests launch separation

This feature is implemented as a method that returns regex string (file `.jenkinsci/test-launcher.groovy`)
This method is called in the `Jenkinsfile` stage `Tests` and its return string is passed as a parameter to the `doTestStep()` method. More detailed description of test types execution according to the build strategy is provided in the next section (1.6)

#### 1.6 Default order of execution

Table contains requirements for order of pipeline execution. 

|Scenario|Build Behavior|Coverage|Tests|Packages|Docs|Bindings|
|:--:|:--|:--|:--|:--|:--|:--|
|Branch commit|x86_64 gcc-5.4 build|by request|`module` tests|by request|by request|by request|
|Open Pull Request|`x86_64 gcc-5.4`, `MacOS` build|for `x86_64`|`module`|by request|by request|by request|
|Commit Pull Request|`x86_64 gcc-5.4`|by request|`module`|by request|by request|by request|
|Merge to `trunk`|all platforms|by request|`module` for all platforms. for `x86_64 gcc-5.4` run `integration`, `system`, `cmake`, `regression` tests|by request|by request|by request|
|Merge to `develop`|all platforms|by request|`module` for all platforms. for `x86_64 gcc-5.4` run `integration`, `system`, `cmake`, `regression` tests|docker dev|all|all|
|Merge to `master`|all platforms|`x86_64 gcc-5.4`|`module` for all platforms. for `x86_64 gcc-5.4` run `integration`, `system`, `cmake`, `regression` tests|all|all|all|
|Nightly|all platforms|`x86_64 gcc-5.4`|for all platforms run `integration`, `system`, `cmake`, `regression` tests. for `x86_64 gcc-5.4` run all tests|`*.deb`, `*.tar`|none|all|

### 2 Minor changes

- Fixed absence of `--output-on-failure` flag on `MacOS` tests.
- Modified post-step for whole CI allowed to fix execution logic
- Fixed clean-up procedures:
  - separated `linuxPostStep()` method from `jenkinsci/linux-post-step.groovy` into `postStep()` and `cleanUp()` methods. `postStep()` method is authoritative for uploading artifacts after release build, when `cleanUp()` removes folders created during builds
  - fixed the call cases for the `doDockerCleanup()`. Now this method been called only from the pipeline's cleanup post-step, at `armv7`, `armv8` agents.
  - fixed the stale docker images cleanup ([IR-1293](https://soramitsu.atlassian.net/browse/IR-1293), [IR-1451](https://soramitsu.atlassian.net/browse/IR-1451))
## Benefits
- reduced build time (~15-20 mins for branch commit, except branch commit with changes dockerfile, it takes additional 30-50 minutes)
- automatic merge by CI
- defined workflow that covers all scenario

### Usage Examples or Tests *[optional]*

body:
### Description of the Change

Fixing synchronization bug

### Bug reproduction

Create network of 4 nodes.
Start only 3 nodes and send a transaction.
Start the disabled node and send a transaction (so that trigger synchronization)
The last one will fall

### Alternate Designs

Didn't find useful routines in rxcpp, maybe it can be rewritten in more elegant way

title: Add emscripted bindings
body:
### Description of the Change

This PR introduces a new way to build JS library for all platforms by Emscripten.

### Benefits

The first and the most important feature of this PR: we can use compiled library on almost **any** JS platform, particularly on modern **browsers**.
The second, but very important too: we can **sufficiently** decrease efforts to maintain the native code of the NPM package because we no need SWIG anymore!

### Possible Drawbacks 

Maintainers should spend some time to create and maintain *Embind* C++ bindings and JS wrapper code to properly build the lib for Emscripten.
Also, we should create some unit test to ensure binding correctness between C++ and JS types.
The third one drawback is a C++ type system. Not all types and semantic structures (e.g. template-based classes) can be easily turned to JS equivalents. It needs to be previously discussed before introduce such classes and methods to the Shared Library API. And, obviously, developers of Shared Library shouldn't overuse polymorphism.

### Usage Examples or Tests

This library is a drop-in replacement of the previous one. No additional changes in the existing application code needed.

### Alternate Designs

Alternate design can be implemented using WebIDL bind system instead Embind. More information you can find in the [**report**](https://gist.github.com/stinger112/c0ec155a0f4083dd7013d1dd027a6678).

### Additional

Working on this PR still in progress, but most of the functionality (including tests) already working.
Please, don't remove this PR. Thank you :)

### How to build

You can find an instruction with the related docker container [here](https://hub.docker.com/r/stinger112/soramitsu/).

### TODOs

- [x] Create clean docker image with Emscripten's compilation environment
- [ ] Add correct memory management with **shared_ptr** and **deleteLater**
- [x] Add helper functions and classes to JS wrapper
- [x] Enable compiler optimizations
- [x] Actualize the code according actual **Shared Library** in develop
- [x] Cleanup code

### Description of the Change
Java bindings on Jenkins CI are generated with dynamically linked `libed25519.so`. End users do not necessarily have this library installed on the system. This makes Java bindings without `libed25519.so` not usable. This PR fixes this issue by removing ed25519 files from the system prior configuring the build with CMake.

title: Fix segfault when non intialized ITF were destructed
body:
Signed-off-by: Igor Egorov <igor@soramitsu.co.jp>

<!-- You will not see HTML commented line in Pull Request body -->
<!-- Optional sections may be omitted. Just remove them or write None -->

<!-- ### Requirements -->
<!-- * Filling out the template is required. Any pull request that does not include enough information to be reviewed in a timely manner may be closed at the maintainers' discretion. -->
<!-- * All new code must have code coverage above 70% (https://docs.codecov.io/docs/about-code-coverage). -->
<!-- * CircleCI builds must be passed. -->
<!-- * Critical and blocker issues reported by Sorabot must be fixed. -->
<!-- * Branch must be rebased onto base branch (https://soramitsu.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/IS/pages/11173889/Rebase+and+merge+guide). -->


### Description of the Change

No segfault will occur when unused ITF instance is destructed.

<!-- We must be able to understand the design of your change from this description. If we can't get a good idea of what the code will be doing from the description here, the pull request may be closed at the maintainers' discretion. -->
<!-- Keep in mind that the maintainer reviewing this PR may not be familiar with or have worked with the code here recently, so please walk us through the concepts. -->

### Benefits

The following code would not cause segfault:
```
{
  IntegrationTestFramework itf(1);
}
```

<!-- What benefits will be realized by the code change? -->

### Possible Drawbacks 

None

<!-- What are the possible side-effects or negative impacts of the code change? -->
<!-- If no drawbacks, explicitly mention this (write None) -->

### Usage Examples or Tests

```
cmake -Bbuild -H.
cmake --build build --target regression_test
build/test_bin/regression_test --gtest_filter=RegressionTest.DestructionOfNonInitializedItf
```

<!-- Point reviewers to the test, code example or documentation which shows usage example of this feature -->

### Alternate Designs 

The rest of ITF methods such as "sendTx" could also get the fix, but they are left without such check of null pointers as it was done inside "done" method by this fix.
**This is ok**, because "done" will be called automatically inside default ITF deleter passed to destructor and "sendTx" would not. 
Moreover, "sendTx" will generate an exception only in case of strict violation of ITF usage mechanism (calling "sendTx" without calling of "setInitialState").

title: Hyperledger Iroha v1.0.0 beta-2
body:
In this release following changes were made:

## Uploading of Iroha build artifacts

Artifacts are now available on https://artifact.soramitsu.co.jp for downloading:
- macOS Iroha binary
- linux Iroha binaries
- Android, Java, Python bindings

In the following releases, more bindings are coming!  

## Fix of critical vulnerabilities discovered during the security audit

Previously, several problems existed:
- Blocks can be signed more than once by the same peer (fixed in #1193)
- Transactions can be signed more than once by the same signatory (fixed in #1302)

If ed25519 library was modified to use a non-deterministic nonce, these vulnerabilities were likely to be used. Thanks to @dhuseby who helped us to unveil this tricky part of ed25519.

## Message size

Previously, gRPC message was limited to 4MB. Regarding our release stage, we decided to get rid of this limitation. Right now anyone can send huge messages over the peer network. It is a potential attack vector, so we will fix it in following releases.

## Docker naming 

Our docker containers now are described here: https://hub.docker.com/r/hyperledger/iroha/
Please use only them (our docs were also updated in #1337)

## Integration test framework

We fixed the indeterministic outcome of tricky tests, optimized their overall runtime by 15 times on macOS hosts and by 3 times on linux hosts (#1338)

## MSVC

Now our client library (shared model) can be built with Microsoft compiler, and respective tests can be built and ran in this environment. 

Hyperledger Iroha codebase MSVC support is coming in next releases.

## Genesis block generation from a transaction

`iroha-cli --genesis_block --genesis_transaction transaction.json` #1168 

## Error message to response, if stateless validation has failed

`ToriiResponse` has field `error_message` with the error description of a transaction
`ErrorResponse` has field `message` with the error description of a query
`QueryResponse` has hex-encoded query hash instead of binary hash

## Client libraries & shared model

Finished transition to shared model.
Transaction counter is no longer used in the transaction structure. Replay attacks are going to be prevented with transaction hash on peer side.

## Stability

A regular queue is replaced with a priority queue in ordering gate so that proposals are propagated in order to the system if they are received in random order from the network. That causes fewer issues with simulator warnings about last block height being inconsistent with proposal height.

## Bugfixes

- Fixed: streaming
- Fixed: boost linking
- Fixed: numerous synchronization issues
- Fixed: inconsistent genesis block generation
- Fixed: possible fork attacks
- Fixed: numerous permission issues
- Fixed: segfaults when the ledger doesn't contain blocks
- Fixed: numerous memory management issues
- Fixed: copyright and licensing issues (mostly)
- Other minor fixes

## Known issues

- Unlimited gRPC message size
- https://soramitsu.atlassian.net/browse/IR-1267
- https://soramitsu.atlassian.net/browse/IR-1332

If there are errors, please install the package using the following commands: ``` python3 -m pip install google --user python3 -m pip install protobuf --user ``` #### Testing ``` cmake -H. -Bbuild -DSWIG_PYTHON=ON cmake --build build --target irohapy -- -j4 cmake --build build --target python_tests -- -j4 cd build ctest -R python --output-on-failure ```

title: Release notes DRAFT
body:
# DRAFT

### Assets

In this release following changes were made:

## Uploading of the build artifacts
Artifacts will now be available on https://artifact.soramitsu.co.jp for downloading
## Features
- genesis block generation from a list of transactions
#### How to use
`iroha-cli --genesis_block --genesis_transaction transaction.json` @l4l 
- Added: error message to response, if stateless validation has failed
#### How to use
`ToriiResponse` now has field `error_message` with the error description of transaction
`ErrorResponse` now has field `message` with  the error description of query
- QueryResponse now have hex-encoded query hashe instead of binary hashe
## Client libraries & shared model
  - Transaction counter is no longer used in the transaction structure
  - Full transition to shared_model 
## Optimisations
### Performance
- A Regular queue is replaced with a priority queue in ordering gate so that proposals are propagated in order to the system if they are received in random order from the network. That causes fewer issues with simulator warnings about last block height being inconsistent with proposal height.
### Other
- Python and Javascript bindings can be compiled at the same time

### Bugfixes
- Fixed: signature comparing
- Fixed: boost linking
- Fixed: numerous synchronization issues
- Fixed: inconsistent genesis block generation
- Fixed: possible fork attacks
- Fixed: numerous permission issues
- Fixed: segfaults when the ledger doesn't contain blocks
- Fixed: numerous memory management issues
- Other minor fixes

title: Automate Docker manifest uploading
body:
Signed-off-by: Artyom Bakhtin <a@bakhtin.net>

<!-- You will not see HTML commented line in Pull Request body -->
<!-- Optional sections may be omitted. Just remove them or write None -->

<!-- ### Requirements -->
<!-- * Filling out the template is required. Any pull request that does not include enough information to be reviewed in a timely manner may be closed at the maintainers' discretion. -->
<!-- * All new code must have code coverage above 70% (https://docs.codecov.io/docs/about-code-coverage). -->
<!-- * CircleCI builds must be passed. -->
<!-- * Critical and blocker issues reported by Sorabot must be fixed. -->
<!-- * Branch must be rebased onto base branch (https://soramitsu.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/IS/pages/11173889/Rebase+and+merge+guide). -->


### Description of the Change
Introduce automatic updates of Docker manifest file with each push to Docker registry. Previously it was uploaded manually once (`docker/manifest.yaml`) using `manifest-tool` Go-written program. It was considered sufficient and assumed that each successive update of an image under some tag would update its parent reference. Turned out we must reupload manifest file with each push of the tag. Instead of using `manifest-tool` this PR exploits a new feature introduced in Docker 18. It allows to manipulate manifest file using Docker CLI itself.
<!-- We must be able to understand the design of your change from this description. If we can't get a good idea of what the code will be doing from the description here, the pull request may be closed at the maintainers' discretion. -->
<!-- Keep in mind that the maintainer reviewing this PR may not be familiar with or have worked with the code here recently, so please walk us through the concepts. -->

### Benefits

<!-- What benefits will be realized by the code change? -->
Always up-to-date Docker manifest file
### Possible Drawbacks 

<!-- What are the possible side-effects or negative impacts of the code change? -->
<!-- If no drawbacks, explicitly mention this (write None) -->
Slightly slower Jenkins CI builds (~3-4s degradation per build)

### Description of the Change
New version of gRPC introduced another library file, which was not copied in Dockerfile. Any such change in gRPC will require manual maintenance of library list, which is not convenient. This pull request reverts gRPC installation logic to `cmake --target install`, so that all required libraries are installed independent of version.

Each parameter of either command or query is tested separately from other parameters for boundary values (in a moment only one method's parameter takes invalid value - the rest are provided with valid values). The total number of tests for commands is 96, queries - 47. | Iroha Command | Tests | | --- | --- | | | emptyTx | | **AddPeer** | addPeer

title: Add prefix with type of test for Ctest names
body:
### Description of the Change

Add the type of tests for Ctest names. Type of test is fetching from the source path of the test.
Currently available the following prefixes:
* "module_" for unit tests
* "regression_" for finding regressions
* "integration_" for integration tests
* and "system_" for system tests, respectively.

### Benefits
Possible to build only required tests for different cases in CI

### Possible Drawbacks 
Name of tests is not a same with the name of a target.

title: Remove clearSignatures method
body:
### Description of the Change
The shared model had the method that clean signatures inside an object. This method is not suitable for the philosophy of sh_m objects - this method does object invalid in terms of stateless validation. 


### Benefits
Remove method that breaks stateless validation for sh_m objects.

### Possible Drawbacks 
We have to check the stability of bindings by ourself. CI cannot handle it now.

title: Experimental MSVC shared model build
body:
<!-- You will not see HTML commented line in Pull Request body -->
<!-- Optional sections may be omitted. Just remove them or write None -->

<!-- ### Requirements -->
<!-- * Filling out the template is required. Any pull request that does not include enough information to be reviewed in a timely manner may be closed at the maintainers' discretion. -->
<!-- * All new code must have code coverage above 70% (https://docs.codecov.io/docs/about-code-coverage). -->

<!-- * Critical and blocker issues reported by Sorabot must be fixed. -->
<!-- * Branch must be rebased onto base branch (https://soramitsu.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/IS/pages/11173889/Rebase+and+merge+guide). -->


### Description of the Change
Changes allowing MSVC build of shared model. Only installed protobuf and gtest are supported due to more complicated shared library linking on Windows.
<!-- We must be able to understand the design of your change from this description. If we can't get a good idea of what the code will be doing from the description here, the pull request may be closed at the maintainers' discretion. -->
<!-- Keep in mind that the maintainer reviewing this PR may not be familiar with or have worked with the code here recently, so please walk us through the concepts. -->

### Benefits
Develop shared model on Windows!
<!-- What benefits will be realized by the code change? -->

### Possible Drawbacks 
"Redundant" `ciso646` includes.
<!-- What are the possible side-effects or negative impacts of the code change? -->
<!-- If no drawbacks, explicitly mention this (write None) -->

### Usage Examples or Tests
- `choco install visualstudio2017-workload-vctools` - Microsoft compilers
- `choco install cmake` - CMake
- Install [vcpkg](https://github.com/Microsoft/vcpkg) as described
- Install the packages: `vcpkg install protobuf:x86-windows gtest:x86-windows boost-multiprecision:x86-windows boost-variant:x86-windows boost-format:x86-windows boost-serialization:x86-windows boost-algorithm:x86-windows boost-conversion:x86-windows`
- Open toolchain console: Start-Visual Studio 2017-x86 Native Tools Command Prompt for VS 2017

- `cmake --build C:\path\to\build --config Debug`

title: Fix peer query race condition
body:
<!-- You will not see HTML commented line in Pull Request body -->
<!-- Optional sections may be omitted. Just remove them or write None -->

<!-- ### Requirements -->
<!-- * Filling out the template is required. Any pull request that does not include enough information to be reviewed in a timely manner may be closed at the maintainers' discretion. -->
<!-- * All new code must have code coverage above 70% (https://docs.codecov.io/docs/about-code-coverage). -->
<!-- * CircleCI builds must be passed. -->
<!-- * Critical and blocker issues reported by Sorabot must be fixed. -->
<!-- * Branch must be rebased onto base branch (https://soramitsu.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/IS/pages/11173889/Rebase+and+merge+guide). -->


### Description of the Change
Block loader, consensus, and ordering service can access peer query concurrently, which may lead to race condition if same connection is reused, because postgres connection does not handle concurrent accesses. Separate connection are used in these components now.
<!-- We must be able to understand the design of your change from this description. If we can't get a good idea of what the code will be doing from the description here, the pull request may be closed at the maintainers' discretion. -->
<!-- Keep in mind that the maintainer reviewing this PR may not be familiar with or have worked with the code here recently, so please walk us through the concepts. -->

### Benefits
Less race conditions, more stable tests
<!-- What benefits will be realized by the code change? -->

### Possible Drawbacks 
At least two new connections to database. Probably a more elegant way can be found later with a connection pool for example.
<!-- What are the possible side-effects or negative impacts of the code change? -->
<!-- If no drawbacks, explicitly mention this (write None) -->

### Description of the Change
- Rework GIT_PREVIOUS_COMMIT variable null-value check
- Fix Coverage stage run even it is supposed to be disabled
- Fix `parallelism` variable not set properly for ARMv7 platform builds
- Force checking `when` conditional prior occupying an agent 

<!-- We must be able to understand the design of your change from this description. If we can't get a good idea of what the code will be doing from the description here, the pull request may be closed at the maintainers' discretion. -->
<!-- Keep in mind that the maintainer reviewing this PR may not be familiar with or have worked with the code here recently, so please walk us through the concepts. -->

### Benefits
- Speed up builds for the first branch commit as we download Dockerfile from a correct URL the image for which is usually present on a FS
- Speed up builds by skipping over Coverage stage when not needed
- Speed up builds by not waiting in stages to check for `when` step results. E.g., ARMv7 is usually skipped but still requires to allocate an agent to execute `when` step. Not needed anymore.
<!-- What benefits will be realized by the code change? -->

### Possible Drawbacks 
None

title: CI fixes
body:
<!-- You will not see HTML commented line in Pull Request body -->
<!-- Optional sections may be omitted. Just remove them or write None -->

<!-- ### Requirements -->
<!-- * Filling out the template is required. Any pull request that does not include enough information to be reviewed in a timely manner may be closed at the maintainers' discretion. -->
<!-- * All new code must have code coverage above 70% (https://docs.codecov.io/docs/about-code-coverage). -->
<!-- * CircleCI builds must be passed. -->
<!-- * Critical and blocker issues reported by Sorabot must be fixed. -->
<!-- * Branch must be rebased onto base branch (https://soramitsu.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/IS/pages/11173889/Rebase+and+merge+guide). -->


### Description of the Change
- Rework Docker images naming scheme. Previously, it was ambiguous and did not reflect the contents of an image. Scheme now looks the following:
    - `iroha:latest` — master branch, image with Iroha installed
    - `iroha:develop` — develop branch, image with Iroha installed
    - `iroha:develop-build` — develop branch, image with dependencies for building Iroha
Naming scheme is described in `manifest.yaml` file. The file will be uploaded into Dockerhub after this PR is merged
- Remove Dockerfile division by platform (x86_64, ARM) as platform-aware dependencies are eliminated
- Postgres Docker container in debug build is now started along with Iroha build container, not separately. This simplifies tear-down procedure as Postgres container shuts down automatically
- Remove nightly build related scripts. Nightly build is now a separate job on Jenkins
- Rework Docker-compose file
- Increase log verbosity in case of failed tests

<!-- We must be able to understand the design of your change from this description. If we can't get a good idea of what the code will be doing from the description here, the pull request may be closed at the maintainers' discretion. -->
<!-- Keep in mind that the maintainer reviewing this PR may not be familiar with or have worked with the code here recently, so please walk us through the concepts. -->

### Benefits
- Build status of PRs on Github will not be affected by nightly build status
- Eliminate ambiguity in Docker images naming scheme
<!-- What benefits will be realized by the code change? -->

### Possible Drawbacks 
None
<!-- What are the possible side-effects or negative impacts of the code change? -->

title: Rework ordering service event handling
body:
<!-- You will not see HTML commented line in Pull Request body -->
<!-- Optional sections may be omitted. Just remove them or write None -->

<!-- ### Requirements -->
<!-- * Filling out the template is required. Any pull request that does not include enough information to be reviewed in a timely manner may be closed at the maintainers' discretion. -->
<!-- * All new code must have code coverage above 70% (https://docs.codecov.io/docs/about-code-coverage). -->
<!-- * CircleCI builds must be passed. -->
<!-- * Critical and blocker issues reported by Sorabot must be fixed. -->
<!-- * Branch must be rebased onto base branch (https://soramitsu.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/IS/pages/11173889/Rebase+and+merge+guide). -->


### Description of the Change
Fix issues with heap-use-after-free and `generateProposal` thread working after destructor.
 - `unsubscribe` call now blocks until a running method is completed
 - no more mutex for destructor
 - mutex is used when a transaction is received from the network, so that subject calls are not concurrent
 - queue size is verified when subscriber is called, and not when event is received
<!-- We must be able to understand the design of your change from this description. If we can't get a good idea of what the code will be doing from the description here, the pull request may be closed at the maintainers' discretion. -->
<!-- Keep in mind that the maintainer reviewing this PR may not be familiar with or have worked with the code here recently, so please walk us through the concepts. -->

### Benefits
More stable implementation
<!-- What benefits will be realized by the code change? -->

### Possible Drawbacks 
Code duplication in constructor caused by templates in rxcpp, which are only removed after `subscribe`. A possible solution is to pass coordination as template parameter, but this will require some type rework and renaming.
<!-- What are the possible side-effects or negative impacts of the code change? -->
<!-- If no drawbacks, explicitly mention this (write None) -->

title: Add result utilities
body: ### Description of the Change Utility functions for result usage: - has_val - has_err - some_val (fixture) - some_err (fixture) - and_res - or_res - rmap - rmap_error And test & doc for them Replaced with stricter analogue: `ASSERT_NO_THROW` + `checkValueCase` -> `ASSERT_TRUE` + `val` `ASSERT_NO_THROW` + `checkErrorCase` -> `ASSERT_TRUE` + `err` Replaced as more generic: `checkValueCase` -> `val` `checkErrorCase` -> `err` ### Benefits There will be much more readable code that deals with multiple errors, eg this block: https://github.com/hyperledger/iroha/blob/master/irohad/execution/impl/command_executor.cpp#L89 ### Possible Drawbacks None ### Tests changed - ametsuchi_test - command_validate_execute_test - result_test - wsv_query_command_test

title: Fix artifacts uploading
body:
Signed-off-by: Artyom Bakhtin <a@bakhtin.net>

<!-- You will not see HTML commented line in Pull Request body -->
<!-- Optional sections may be omitted. Just remove them or write None -->

<!-- ### Requirements -->
<!-- * Filling out the template is required. Any pull request that does not include enough information to be reviewed in a timely manner may be closed at the maintainers' discretion. -->
<!-- * All new code must have code coverage above 70% (https://docs.codecov.io/docs/about-code-coverage). -->
<!-- * CircleCI builds must be passed. -->
<!-- * Critical and blocker issues reported by Sorabot must be fixed. -->
<!-- * Branch must be rebased onto base branch (https://soramitsu.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/IS/pages/11173889/Rebase+and+merge+guide). -->


### Description of the Change

- "Debug" build type build followed by "Release" build in CI pipeline generates two sets of artifacts for each build type respectively. This PR disables artifacts generation for "Debug" build type so that they would not be uploaded to artifact server. We only want to have "Release" artifacts published.
- Include TAR packaged artifacts previously generated but not uploaded for Linux builds.
- Replace `cp` with `mv` to save some disk space used by a single build.

<!-- We must be able to understand the design of your change from this description. If we can't get a good idea of what the code will be doing from the description here, the pull request may be closed at the maintainers' discretion. -->
<!-- Keep in mind that the maintainer reviewing this PR may not be familiar with or have worked with the code here recently, so please walk us through the concepts. -->

### Benefits
- Only "Release" artifacts are uploaded
- TAR packaged binaries for non-Debian OS flavors
- Reduce disk space usage during a CI build
<!-- What benefits will be realized by the code change? -->

### Possible Drawbacks 
None
<!-- What are the possible side-effects or negative impacts of the code change? -->
<!-- If no drawbacks, explicitly mention this (write None) -->

title: Multisignature transactions support
body:
### Description of the Change

Introduce multisignature transactions support.
That pr should be merged only after:

- [x] merging of #1066
- [x] adding type for MstExpired in shared model (#1279)
- [x] reworking mst pipeline test with itf and enabling it (#1281)
- [x] Runtime parameter for enabling mst support (#1286)
- [ ] <s>Add quorum fields for bindings</s> (IR-1348)
- [ ] <s>Rework gossip propagation</s> (IR-1349)

### Possible Drawbacks 

The main codebase maybe unstable after merging, as long as that branch is really long-living

### Usage Examples or Tests

All tests related to transaction have been updated. So new transaction must contain quorum param, that by default is 1 (or bigger, if transaction should be multisig)

title: Python/Java/Android bindings
body:
Signed-off-by: Artyom Bakhtin <a@bakhtin.net>

<!-- You will not see HTML commented line in Pull Request body -->
<!-- Optional sections may be omitted. Just remove them or write None -->

<!-- ### Requirements -->
<!-- * Filling out the template is required. Any pull request that does not include enough information to be reviewed in a timely manner may be closed at the maintainers' discretion. -->
<!-- * All new code must have code coverage above 70% (https://docs.codecov.io/docs/about-code-coverage). -->
<!-- * CircleCI builds must be passed. -->
<!-- * Critical and blocker issues reported by Sorabot must be fixed. -->
<!-- * Branch must be rebased onto base branch (https://soramitsu.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/IS/pages/11173889/Rebase+and+merge+guide). -->


### Description of the Change
CI:
- added Android bindings generation. Based on [this script](https://github.com/hyperledger/iroha/blob/e70649f7288499cd27a66788b06b3cc1706cb416/example/Android/android-build.sh). Dockerfile in `android/Dockerfile` contains instructions for building base image. Iroha itself then checked out into Docker container with necessary changes in `CMakeLists.txt`. Dockerfile supports building for multiple platforms, ABIs and build types (`PLATFORM`, `VERSION` and `BUILD_TYPE_A` variables respectively). Allowed parameters are defined in the beginning of Jenkinsfile as properties.
- rewrite Python and Java bindings generation. Added support for Python 2.7 as suggested by @l4l [here](https://github.com/hyperledger/iroha/pull/1170#pullrequestreview-109064226)
- rewrite [`dockerPullOrUpdate`](https://github.com/hyperledger/iroha/blob/fe0dd0ec77f871a778864fe904fd3ae6ac5695bc/.jenkinsci/docker-pull-or-build.groovy) function to support Docker images required to build bindings. Fix the function exit with an error in case Docker images is unavailable in Dockerhub. It now builds an image instead.

Regarding [forced dependencies resolving](https://github.com/hyperledger/iroha/pull/1170#issuecomment-378348753) by @l4l. [As explained](https://github.com/hyperledger/iroha/pull/1170#issuecomment-378573268) by @luckychess, appropriate protobuf version must be installed.
Regarding [ed25519 packaging](https://github.com/hyperledger/iroha/pull/1170#issuecomment-378348753). `libed25519`  is linked statically and not shown in the `ldd` output

#1179 is no more relevant

<!-- We must be able to understand the design of your change from this description. If we can't get a good idea of what the code will be doing from the description here, the pull request may be closed at the maintainers' discretion. -->
<!-- Keep in mind that the maintainer reviewing this PR may not be familiar with or have worked with the code here recently, so please walk us through the concepts. -->

### Benefits
Bindings for multiple languages and platforms will now be available without struggling of building it themselves. 
<!-- What benefits will be realized by the code change? -->

### Possible Drawbacks 
None
<!-- What are the possible side-effects or negative impacts of the code change? -->
<!-- If no drawbacks, explicitly mention this (write None) -->

### Usage Examples
Bindings building is switched off by default. In order to build it, one should log into [Jenkins](https://jenkins.soramitsu.co.jp), navigate to `develop` branch and click `Build with parameters` on the left. Setup the platform you wish to build the bindings for and start the build.
Upon successful build, bindings will be uploaded to [artifact server](https://artifact.soramitsu.co.jp) into `bindings` folder

### Description of the Change

This pr change QueryResponse.query_hash to be a hex-encoded string instead of byte array.

### Benefits

Since this data is returned inside a json object is should have a hex representation - similar to transaction hashes. Binary strings can be a problem to deal with in some client languages. 

### Possible Drawbacks 
--

title: Fix/on absent genesis block
body:
### Description of the Change
Fix segfault when the ledger doesn't contain blocks.

### Benefits
Minus one segfault in the project.
Also, bring little fix plus improvement for `itf::config_helper`: remove redundant include and logging for pg credentials.

### Possible Drawbacks 
Absent test for checking the new behavior. And I don't see a theoretical opportunity to write it.
So, reviewers should check it manually.

### Description of the Change

Unfortunately, the data used in the documentation are obsolete and have been supposed to be replaced before release of beta. We should not keep this metric for too long in public, as Iroha is expected to produce 3000 tx/s throughput on 7 nodes. As we are in the middle of update of Huawei Caliper's data then we need to finish it first and only then update data in docs.

### Benefits

Relevant data in docs.

### Possible Drawbacks 

None

title: Fix permission bug
body:
Signed-off-by: kamilsa <kamilsa16@gmail.com>

<!-- You will not see HTML commented line in Pull Request body -->
<!-- Optional sections may be omitted. Just remove them or write None -->

<!-- ### Requirements -->
<!-- * Filling out the template is required. Any pull request that does not include enough information to be reviewed in a timely manner may be closed at the maintainers' discretion. -->
<!-- * All new code must have code coverage above 70% (https://docs.codecov.io/docs/about-code-coverage). -->
<!-- * CircleCI builds must be passed. -->
<!-- * Critical and blocker issues reported by Sorabot must be fixed. -->
<!-- * Branch must be rebased onto base branch (https://soramitsu.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/IS/pages/11173889/Rebase+and+merge+guide). -->


### Description of the Change

Fixes problem of missed grantable permissions in proto file. 

Bug example:
User "userone@domain" wants to grant user "usertwo@domain" to add key value information. To do so "userone@domaiun" needed to grant "can_set_my_account_detail" permission to "usertwo@permission". But to do so user "userone@domain" needs permission "can_grant_can_set_my_quorum" which was missing before in proto files although existed in iroha.

### Benefits

Includes missing permissions to proto file.

### Possible Drawbacks 

None

### Usage Examples or Tests

tx-example.py has been updated to demonstrate granting permission to set account detail to another user, set it, and check if detail has been set.

title: Fix/ir 1122
body:
### Description of the Change

This PR fixes bug that synchronizer can apply any valid chain. The following is achieved by checking the chain ending that is expected to be same block as in commit message.  

### Benefits

Peers are protected against fork attacks, when malicious (but voting) peer gives valid but forked chain.

### Possible Drawbacks 

The peer must be synchronized within one round, as the chain ending must be as the commit message.

title: Feature/grpc logging
body:
### Description of the Change

RPC errors are not logged, the pr changes that by moving logger from children of `AsyncGrpcClient` to the parent. Also adds some additional logging.

Note, that grpc errors can be observed via **GRPC_TRACE**/**GRPC_VERBOSITY** env variables, but they mostly are not human-friendly

### Benefits

More logging

### Possible Drawbacks 

None

title: Changed ios build script to use https for all git clone operations (f…
body:
Changed ios build script to use https for all git clone operations (fixed issue with connection timeout)

<!-- You will not see HTML commented line in Pull Request body -->
<!-- Optional sections may be omitted. Just remove them or write None -->

<!-- ### Requirements -->
<!-- * Filling out the template is required. Any pull request that does not include enough information to be reviewed in a timely manner may be closed at the maintainers' discretion. -->

<!-- * Branch must be rebased onto base branch (https://soramitsu.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/IS/pages/11173889/Rebase+and+merge+guide). -->


### Description of the Change

Just a small improvement for ios-build bash script - on local machines it's safer to use https URL for clone operations. Currently, the script contains "git:" schema which may cause connection timeout while executing it. 
<!-- We must be able to understand the design of your change from this description. If we can't get a good idea of what the code will be doing from the description here, the pull request may be closed at the maintainers' discretion. -->
<!-- Keep in mind that the maintainer reviewing this PR may not be familiar with or have worked with the code here recently, so please walk us through the concepts. -->

### Benefits

Solves issue with "connection timeout" for iroha-ed25519
Code style - all other script parts use https URL to clone repositories

<!-- What benefits will be realized by the code change? -->

### Possible Drawbacks 

There are no impacts - it's a common way to clone git repositories

<!-- What are the possible side-effects or negative impacts of the code change? -->

title: Rework Docker images pull mechanism
body:
Signed-off-by: Artyom Bakhtin <a@bakhtin.net>

<!-- You will not see HTML commented line in Pull Request body -->
<!-- Optional sections may be omitted. Just remove them or write None -->

<!-- ### Requirements -->
<!-- * Filling out the template is required. Any pull request that does not include enough information to be reviewed in a timely manner may be closed at the maintainers' discretion. -->
<!-- * All new code must have code coverage above 70% (https://docs.codecov.io/docs/about-code-coverage). -->
<!-- * CircleCI builds must be passed. -->
<!-- * Critical and blocker issues reported by Sorabot must be fixed. -->
<!-- * Branch must be rebased onto base branch (https://soramitsu.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/IS/pages/11173889/Rebase+and+merge+guide). -->


### Description of the Change
Before this PR, Jenkins has been building Docker images prior running every build. The procedure is the following:
- forcibly build Docker image referenced by current commit. In majority of cases Docker reuses image layers local cache and simply tags already existing image
- in case any changes were introduced in Docker file, the image is rebuilt and used while building Iroha
- in case the current build is recognized as Master or Develop branch commit, resulting Docker image is uploaded to Dockerhub
The problem is that in the very beginning of Dockerfile we run `apt-get update` command followed by `apt-get upgrade`

```
RUN apt-get update; \
    apt-get -y upgrade; \
    apt-get -y --no-install-recommends install apt-utils software-properties-common; \
    apt-get -y clean
[snip]
```

Docker decides whether the `RUN` section is in cache or not totally depends on the similarity of commands, i.e. if no changes were introduced into a `RUN` section, Docker will reuse local cache. This works fine as long as we do not need to update `apt` cache. And sometimes we must do it because repositories are referenced by DNS names and not by IP addresses. However, those resolved domain names are stored in APT cache as IP addresses, which may become unavailable over time.
This leads to a situation when modified Dockerfile, that was added with additional packages installed from APT repositories cannot install them, as IP addresses not available any more. This requires APT cache to be updated with `apt-get update` command. And as Docker reuses local cache this operation will never run.
We can force Docker to always update cache before every build, but this leads to rebuilding the whole image, because `apt-get update` is the very first command in Dockerfile

This PR introduces a new mechanism for building Docker images during pipeline run. We compare Dockerfile of two consecutive commits: current and the previous one. If they differ, then simply rebuild an an image. Otherwise, reuse the image already built in the previous commit.

<!-- We must be able to understand the design of your change from this description. If we can't get a good idea of what the code will be doing from the description here, the pull request may be closed at the maintainers' discretion. -->
<!-- Keep in mind that the maintainer reviewing this PR may not be familiar with or have worked with the code here recently, so please walk us through the concepts. -->

### Benefits
Docker images that are built during pipeline run will now avoid stale APT repositories, while still benefit from already built images during previous pipeline runs.

<!-- What benefits will be realized by the code change? -->

### Possible Drawbacks 
This may increase pipeline run time in cases a Dockerfile has been changed as we now do not use local layer cache, but rebuilding the entire image. But doing so allows to avoid stale APT repositories, which would have failed a build anyways.

<!-- What are the possible side-effects or negative impacts of the code change? -->
<!-- If no drawbacks, explicitly mention this (write None) -->

<!-- * All new code must have code coverage above 70% (https://docs.codecov.io/docs/about-code-coverage). -->
<!-- * CircleCI builds must be passed. -->
<!-- * Critical and blocker issues reported by Sorabot must be fixed. -->
<!-- * Branch must be rebased onto base branch (https://soramitsu.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/IS/pages/11173889/Rebase+and+merge+guide). -->


### Description of the Change
Consensus was getting locked on two nodes because commit was sent to network after performing synchronous actions of subscribers to commit notification. Sending commit to network before notification fixes this issue.
<!-- We must be able to understand the design of your change from this description. If we can't get a good idea of what the code will be doing from the description here, the pull request may be closed at the maintainers' discretion. -->
<!-- Keep in mind that the maintainer reviewing this PR may not be familiar with or have worked with the code here recently, so please walk us through the concepts. -->

### Benefits
Less locks due to consensus subscribers.
<!-- What benefits will be realized by the code change? -->

### Possible Drawbacks 
It is hard to test at the moment, because it requires integration test with 2+ nodes.
<!-- What are the possible side-effects or negative impacts of the code change? -->
<!-- If no drawbacks, explicitly mention this (write None) -->

### Description of the Change
- Replace usage of `dpkg` command in release Dockerfiles with `apt-get install` as `dpkg` do not resolve package dependencies and fails a build
- Replace release Dockerfiles symlinks with actual files as symlinks are not resolved on Jenkins slaves
- Added `--no-cache` option while building release version of Docker images. That is to prevent hitting broken APT repositories because of not executing `apt-get update` command in Dockerfile.
