title: Smart contracts
body: There  must be a design for the smart contracts and it has been proposed that we need to be aware of using a proper compatible language instead of using either of the Solidity or Go. We might go for scala or else we can define a development environment for the same so that programmers feel free to write, irrespective of anything.

title: Interledger transaction
body:
There must be a common protocol for ensuring that transactions can be made in between ledgers. This is a proposal made in regard with the same.

I do believe that we have to design a common protocol for the Hyperledger Fabric and Iroha. The idea of 2 phase commit seems relevant as we could connect the two ledgers through a common connector which could be linked through the same set of checks. Moreover, Hyperledger Fabric offers a modular architecture for the network designers to plug in their preferred implementations for the components.
There would a common business network for both of them and each main chain operates one or multiple applications/solutions validated by the same group of organizations. Separate Confidential chains should  be built for each of them.

There won't be any need for multiple signatures for making a transaction as there would be confdential chaincode transaction where Validators will only be able to decrypt it. There are different sets of Peers, Proxy Peers, Endorsers and Validators for the peer review of any transactions. Hence, we could think of inter ledger transactions in this way.

Inter-chain transactions and Inter Network transactions can be  made possible between two main networks and between two confidential chains respectively. Chaincodes in a confidential chain can trigger transactions on one or multiple main chain(s).

body:

<!-- * All new code must have code coverage above 70% (https://docs.codecov.io/docs/about-code-coverage). -->
<!-- * CircleCI builds must be passed. -->
<!-- * Critical and blocker issues reported by Sorabot must be fixed. -->
<!-- * Branch must be rebased onto base branch (https://soramitsu.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/IS/pages/11173889/Rebase+and+merge+guide). -->


### Description of the Change

Introduces stateless validation rules and updates corresponding tests tests.

| domain_id    | RFC1035, RFC1123 (disallows the root white space)                             |
|--------------|-------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| address      | IP address of added peer                                                      |
| peer_key     | Public-key of added peer                                                      |
| asset_name   | [a-z_0-9]{1,32}                                                               |
| asset_id     | <asset_name>#<domain_id>                                                      |
| account_name | [a-z_0-9]{1,32}                                                               |
| account_id   | <account_name>@<domain_id>                                                    |
| role_id      | [a-z_0-9]{1,32}                                                               |
| permissions  | See 5.2 Permission                                                            |
| key          | Key of set account detail  [A-Za-z0-9_]{1,64}                                 |
| detail       | ≤ 4096                                                                        |
| quorum       | Number, 0 < quorum ≤ public-key set up to account ≤ 128                       |
| public_key   | Public-key, 32 digits                                                         |
| hash         | Hash value of sha3, 32 digits                                                 |
| created_time | UNIX epoch time, 13 digits in milliseconds, ≤ 24 hours including current time |
| amount       | amount,≥ 0                                                                    |

### Benefits

We have clarified stateless validation rules and updated iroha correspondingly

### Possible Drawbacks 

None

title: Hyperledger Iroha v1.0 beta release
body:
After beta release, we are moving to the schema of time-based releases, and it is expected to release approximately every month.

In this release following changes were made:

## Client libraries & shared model

Our long road, taking its start from a decision made back in October 2017 about using in Iroha daemon a set of _shared_ model classes with invariants, validators, protobuf as a backbone, clear and intuitive validation output, used both on client side and on server side is coming to its end with a release of libraries for several platforms:
* Obviously, C++ 
* Java & Android in particular
* Python

_Shared model_ name means that exactly the same Transaction, Query, etc. objects are used on client and peer side for the purpose of improved reliability and user-friendliness. We are approaching the end of complete migration to these classes (it appears that we will ship it in next release).

A shared model name is going to change to _irohalib_ for a better consistency with UNIX naming style (as Iroha binary is named as irohad).

All libraries except C++ are generated using SWIG — which means that their maintenance is guaranteed by an effective CI pipeline that we are going to build in the future.  So far, libraries are available in several external repositories (Maven, PIP, etc.) and their update is going to be automated in following releases as well.

Swift & Objective-C library is available is a preview state, since there are issues with tests, documentation, and Objective-C code.

NodeJS library is also available in a preview state, though it has tests and documentation for it.

Please, use our documentation related to client libraries on ReadTheDocs service, which is explained below:

## Documentation

Previously, documentation for the project was discrete and was placed in several places, moreover, it was targeted only at developers.

We are changing the focus by telling more people in different languages about key features of Iroha, and the level of technical expertise required to read the docs is varied from integrators or explorers to blockchain developers. 

Check out our new docs at iroha.readthedocs.io (being still translated and changed). 
Please, contribute to the translation of docs [here on POEditor](https://poeditor.com/join/project/SFpZw7o33o).

## Project distribution

One of SnapCraft maintainers, @elopio, has recently contributed with a setup of snap package or Iroha. Please stay tuned as we will publish information on how to use snap right after release. 

As usual, anyone can download docker image and deploy Iroha in a container — check [Getting Started section](http://iroha.readthedocs.io/en/latest/getting_started/). 

In the future, all builds are going to be stored at https://artifact.soramitsu.co.jp/ page.

## Stateless validation

We have changed rules for our transaction, query, etc. schemas to be valid by unifying stateless validation rules. Please check [Core Concepts](http://iroha.readthedocs.io/en/latest/core_concepts/) page of ReadTheDocs, where it is explained what is exactly stateless validation, and how certain fields are validated.

## Integration Test Framework

Acceptance tests are written using Integration Test framework, allowing to set up a context for a transaction pipeline in an easy way. This framework is capable of performing checks all along the pipeline and is reducing code duplication greatly. Readme file explaining ITF is going to be written soon, but for now, please [explore the code](https://github.com/hyperledger/iroha/blob/develop/test/framework/integration_framework/integration_test_framework.hpp) — it is well documented and there are already tests written, and some of the [tests are already reported](https://soramitsu.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/IS/pages/299958273/Acceptance+Tests) (acceptance testing is now in progress).

## Ansible deployment

Now, Ansible playbook improvements allow you to deploy Iroha easily on many physical machines or in many docker containers on a fixed amount of machines to simulate different network configurations. More information is available in README.md file of deploy/ansible folder.

## Torii

Optimizations are now all along the code of our frontend gRPC component (named Torii). Moreover, clients now are not forced to pull the status of a transaction, but instead, they can use pull-based notification mechanism (gRPC Streaming). Check client libraries section for more examples and information. 

## Optimisations

### Reduced amount of project dependencies
* Redis component was removed completely, and PostgreSQL indices are used instead
* Using platform-independent file operations for better portability (still no Windows, sorry)
* Removed legacy code (old tests, crypto files, old schema files)

### Performance
* Added a queue at Ordering Gate — which means that proposals are now waiting in line to be sent to Ordering Service
* Improved performance of Ordering Service component 500 times after removing Proposal copying
* Initial performance testing for 4, 16, 28, 64 nodes

### Other
* Improved line coverage (command executor, Yet Another Consensus)
* Removed nonstd::optional (we are using boost::optional now)
* Clang formatting as a CMake function
* Improved logging
* Tests (more negative test cases, a whole new system test)
* Fixed memory leaks in Torii component
* Secured private keys with a passphrase for a safe storage on HDD

## Bugfixes
* Allow querying all account data
* Ninja build
* CLI improvements (still, it is better to write a new one, but we are supporting what we have at the moment)
* YAC peer order was fixed
* Startup of Ordering Service
* Fixed back pressure on fast proposal emitting

title: Feature/improve run iroha dev
body:
<!-- You will not see HTML commented line in Pull Request body -->
<!-- Optional sections may be omitted. Just remove them or write None -->

<!-- ### Requirements -->
<!-- * Filling out the template is required. Any pull request that does not include enough information to be reviewed in a timely manner may be closed at the maintainers' discretion. -->
<!-- * All new code must have code coverage above 70% (https://docs.codecov.io/docs/about-code-coverage). -->
<!-- * CircleCI builds must be passed. -->
<!-- * Critical and blocker issues reported by Sorabot must be fixed. -->
<!-- * Branch must be rebased onto base branch (https://soramitsu.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/IS/pages/11173889/Rebase+and+merge+guide). -->


### Description of the Change

This PR changes the behavior of **run-iroha-dev.sh** and introduces **stop-iroha-dev.sh**.

<!-- We must be able to understand the design of your change from this description. If we can't get a good idea of what the code will be doing from the description here, the pull request may be closed at the maintainers' discretion. -->
<!-- Keep in mind that the maintainer reviewing this PR may not be familiar with or have worked with the code here recently, so please walk us through the concepts. -->

### Benefits

Managment of container environment comes more clear and intuitive.

#### Each user within a system can run own docker container
Now `${UID}` is actually attached to containers' and network names as it was initially designed.
Moreover, there will be no collision between ports which are used on a host system by different containers. The script `run-iroha-dev.sh` now automatically chooses free port from predefined ranges - 50051-50101 for Iroha and 20000-20100 for a debugger.

#### Introduced script for full shutdown of container environment - stop-iroha-dev.sh
If you want to reinitialize or just shutdown container environment, then you can run stop-iroha-dev.sh and script will stop Iroha and Postgres containers, remove them and the network.
_Note that containers of other users will be left untouched._

#### Now it is possible to reenter into the container without its recreation
Launching of run-iroha-dev.sh several times in a row will lead to the creation of container environment at the first time and enter into it, all the next launches will lead only to reentering into the existing environment.

#### run-iroha-dev.sh reports ports used on the host system for Iroha and debugger

You will be provided with the information what ports are used for Iroha and debugger when you enter the container via launching run-iroha-dev.sh. This information will be shown in both cases - environment creation or just reentering into an existing environment.

### Possible Drawbacks 

The scripts need to be tested on macOS. There should be no issues, but development was done on Linux host.
<!-- What are the possible side-effects or negative impacts of the code change? -->
<!-- If no drawbacks, explicitly mention this (write None) -->

### Usage Examples or Tests

`./scripts/run-iroha-dev.sh` - for environment creation and enter into it. If environment already exists you will be just attached to its bash console.

`./scripts/stop-iroha-dev.sh` - stop Iroha and Postgres containers, destroy them, and destroy the network that was established for the environment.
<!-- Point reviewers to the test, code example or documentation which shows usage example of this feature -->

This pull request eliminates overloading of generateKeypair() function (renames one of overloads to fromPrivateKey).

### Benefits

<!-- What benefits will be realized by the code change? -->
For languages which don't support function overload (like Javascript) behaviour is unspecified in general. In case of Javascript it resulted in impossibility to access generateKeypair(seed). Swig does not contain any documented ways to deal with this issue.

### Possible Drawbacks 

<!-- What are the possible side-effects or negative impacts of the code change? -->
<!-- If no drawbacks, explicitly mention this (write None) -->
Client libraries should be rebuilt.

body:

title: Feature/unique ptr in shm copy ir 1115
body:
<!-- You will not see HTML commented line in Pull Request body -->
<!-- Optional sections may be omitted. Just remove them or write None -->

<!-- ### Requirements -->
<!-- * Filling out the template is required. Any pull request that does not include enough information to be reviewed in a timely manner may be closed at the maintainers' discretion. -->
<!-- * All new code must have code coverage above 70% (https://docs.codecov.io/docs/about-code-coverage). -->
<!-- * CircleCI builds must be passed. -->
<!-- * Critical and blocker issues reported by Sorabot must be fixed. -->
<!-- * Branch must be rebased onto base branch (https://soramitsu.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/IS/pages/11173889/Rebase+and+merge+guide). -->


### Description of the Change
This PR introduces Cloneable interface and clone() function that returns unique_ptr described here (https://github.com/CppCodeReviewers/Covariant-Return-Types-and-Smart-Pointers) to replace shared_model *copy() method that returns raw pointer.
<!-- We must be able to understand the design of your change from this description. If we can't get a good idea of what the code will be doing from the description here, the pull request may be closed at the maintainers' discretion. -->
<!-- Keep in mind that the maintainer reviewing this PR may not be familiar with or have worked with the code here recently, so please walk us through the concepts. -->

### Benefits
Safety with unique_ptr.
<!-- What benefits will be realized by the code change? -->

### Possible Drawbacks 
no
<!-- What are the possible side-effects or negative impacts of the code change? -->
<!-- If no drawbacks, explicitly mention this (write None) -->

### Usage Examples or Tests *[optional]*
```
 // Inherit from clonable with CRTP
 struct Base : object::cloneable<Base>
 {
   // ... other methods
 };

 // override clone() where it is needed
 struct Derived : Base
 {
   // ... other methods
 protected:
   Derived* clone() const override
   {
     return new Derived(*this);
   }
 };

 // and clone with function clone(obj) or clone(obj *)
 Derived derived;
 auto c1 = clone(derived);
 auto c2 = clone(&derived);
```

<!-- Point reviewers to the test, code example or documentation which shows usage example of this feature -->

### Alternate Designs *[optional]*
1. Just override copy() - this approach will hide base.
2. copy() returns unique_ptr<Base> - static_cast needed every time.
3. The same as implemented, but use method instead of function - less general and need to hide base method in every class in hierarchy of shared_model.
<!-- Explain what other alternates were considered and why the proposed version was selected -->

body:
<!-- You will not see HTML commented line in Pull Request body -->
<!-- Optional sections may be omitted. Just remove them or write None -->

<!-- ### Requirements -->
<!-- * Filling out the template is required. Any pull request that does not include enough information to be reviewed in a timely manner may be closed at the maintainers' discretion. -->

<!-- * CircleCI builds must be passed. -->
<!-- * Critical and blocker issues reported by Sorabot must be fixed. -->
<!-- * Branch must be rebased onto base branch (https://soramitsu.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/IS/pages/11173889/Rebase+and+merge+guide). -->


### Description of the Change
This PR introduces NPM package called **iroha-lib**.
It contains an implementation of the shared library for NodeJS, package's build and deploy systems and also a bunch of Iroha fixes, allowing to build **iroha-lib** on Mac and Linux.

Huge thanks to @haojun, @laSinteZ, and @luckychess for help in implementing of this.

<!-- We must be able to understand the design of your change from this description. If we can't get a good idea of what the code will be doing from the description here, the pull request may be closed at the maintainers' discretion. -->
<!-- Keep in mind that the maintainer reviewing this PR may not be familiar with or have worked with the code here recently, so please walk us through the concepts. -->

### Benefits
This allows build and install Iroha library by NPM, so we can use it in Node.js 
<!-- What benefits will be realized by the code change? -->

### Possible Drawbacks 
This is a deep pre-alfa version of the lib, so it can contain some errors, however, I didn't find any.
<!-- What are the possible side-effects or negative impacts of the code change? -->
<!-- If no drawbacks, explicitly mention this (write None) -->

### Usage Examples or Tests *[optional]*
You can watch examples in two places:
1. *shared_model/packages/javascript/example* contains example code distributed with NPM package to test it after installing by `npm install iroha-lib`
2.*example/node* contains working application and some instructions how to run it. This app use **iroha-lib** package.

Now example code in both cases is equal, but it uses for different purposes.  

### Alternate Designs *[optional]*
I had tried to implement build system using NPM packages like **cmake-js** or **node-cmake**, but these technologies seem not very mature yet. Building by such packages allows avoid using **node-gyp**, so we can seamlessly integrate CMake-based build system of Iroha with **iroha-lib** package.

It needs additional research I guess.

title: Fix irohad failing on stopped postgres
body:
### Description of the Change

If psql is stopped during irohad, the last one may cause sigsegv, abort or smth else.
This pr introduces few checks for db activeness

### Benefits

Stability

### Usage Examples or Tests

These steps will cause irohad failing:

1. start postgres
2. start irohad
3. stop postgres
4. send something via iroha-cli

With that fixes it doesn't do anything

### Alternate Designs

Maybe call `std::abort` with meaningful error?

title: Ansible update
body:
Signed-off-by: tyvision <antykushin@gmail.com>

<!-- You will not see HTML commented line in Pull Request body -->
<!-- Optional sections may be omitted. Just remove them or write None -->

<!-- ### Requirements -->
<!-- * Filling out the template is required. Any pull request that does not include enough information to be reviewed in a timely manner may be closed at the maintainers' discretion. -->
<!-- * All new code must have code coverage above 70% (https://docs.codecov.io/docs/about-code-coverage). -->
<!-- * CircleCI builds must be passed. -->
<!-- * Critical and blocker issues reported by Sorabot must be fixed. -->
<!-- * Branch must be rebased onto base branch (https://soramitsu.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/IS/pages/11173889/Rebase+and+merge+guide). -->


### Description of the Change

<!-- We must be able to understand the design of your change from this description. If we can't get a good idea of what the code will be doing from the description here, the pull request may be closed at the maintainers' discretion. -->
<!-- Keep in mind that the maintainer reviewing this PR may not be familiar with or have worked with the code here recently, so please walk us through the concepts. -->

- Created 2 playbooks:
    - playbook (`iroha-standalone-nodes`) deploys 1 iroha+postgres container to each node 
    - playbook (`iroha-docker-cluster`) deploys `N` instances or iroha+postgres to each node using generated `docker-compose.yml` file, where `N` could be specified for each node.
- Changed `docker` role: now `docker-compose` is also installed on target hosts
- Added possibility of rearranging mapped `torii` and `iroha` port in playbook. 
- Automated generation of `peers.list` based on inventory file (stored locally on host where ansible is launched).
- Automated generation of configuration files required for iroha to start: `config.sample`, `genesis.block`, `nodeX.pub`, `nodeX.priv`.  (stored locally)
- Now not only node-specific keypair is distributed to the iroha node.
- Separated roles: there are separated roles to generate files for each node and to deliver them and launch iroha. 
- Changed `ansible.cfg`: acceleration option enabled.
- Added roles and playbook documentation

### Benefits

<!-- What benefits will be realized by the code change? -->
- less handwriting (most of the files are generated automatically by this playbook) 
- increased flexibility as new configuration options added

### Possible Drawbacks 

<!-- What are the possible side-effects or negative impacts of the code change? -->
<!-- If no drawbacks, explicitly mention this (write None) -->
`iroha-cli` (required by roles that generate files locally) built from latest `develop` does invalid `genesis.block` generation:
```

terminate called after throwing an instance of 'boost::exception_detail::clone_impl<boost::exception_detail::error_info_injector<std::out_of_range> >'
  what():  bimap<>: invalid key
```
message is displayed. 

### Usage Examples or Tests *[optional]*
1) change inventory file (to IPs of servers where you would like to test), do not change format unless you know what to do
2) you can change path to your SSH private key in ansible.cfg file, or rename your SSH key to ~/.ssh/sorakey

```
git clone <..>
cd iroha/deploy/ansible
```
to test iroha-standalone-nodes playbook 
```
ansible-playbook -i inventory/test_single.list --private-key=<your_key> playbooks/iroha-standalone-nodes/iroha-deploy.yml
```
or
```
ansible-playbook -i inventory/test_nodes.list --private-key=<your_key> playbooks/iroha-docker-cluster/iroha-deploy.yml
```

title: Edit dev dockerfile: Add libcurl with ssl, set cmake v to 3.7.2
body:
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Vaneev <warchantua@gmail.com>

<!-- You will not see HTML commented line in Pull Request body -->
<!-- Optional sections may be omitted. Just remove them or write None -->

<!-- ### Requirements -->
<!-- * Filling out the template is required. Any pull request that does not include enough information to be reviewed in a timely manner may be closed at the maintainers' discretion. -->
<!-- * All new code must have code coverage above 70% (https://docs.codecov.io/docs/about-code-coverage). -->
<!-- * CircleCI builds must be passed. -->
<!-- * Critical and blocker issues reported by Sorabot must be fixed. -->
<!-- * Branch must be rebased onto base branch (https://soramitsu.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/IS/pages/11173889/Rebase+and+merge+guide). -->


### Description of the Change

<!-- We must be able to understand the design of your change from this description. If we can't get a good idea of what the code will be doing from the description here, the pull request may be closed at the maintainers' discretion. -->
<!-- Keep in mind that the maintainer reviewing this PR may not be familiar with or have worked with the code here recently, so please walk us through the concepts. -->

We compile cmake manually in dev docker, it uses internal libcurl without SSL. Because of this, #1070 build step on circle ci fails with `log: Protocol "https" not supported or disabled in libcurl`.

To fix this I:
- install `libcurl` with `openssl` support.
- I compile cmake with `--system-curl` option, to force cmake use libcurl with ssl cupport

Also, since we use SWIG and it requires cmake 3.7+, I update cmake version to 3.7.2.

### Benefits

<!-- What benefits will be realized by the code change? -->

- this will let us to use hunter in circle ci (build will not fail in #1070)

### Possible Drawbacks 

<!-- What are the possible side-effects or negative impacts of the code change? -->
<!-- If no drawbacks, explicitly mention this (write None) -->

None.


### NOTES

Because both changes (curl + cmake version) are made in a single dockerfile, it is hard for me to do 2 separate PRs for these changes, because each change requires full `hyperledger/iroha-docker-develop:v1` rebuild -- and this process is very slow, so for me it is better to build that image once.

title: Feature/add hunter with boost
body:
<!-- You will not see HTML commented line in Pull Request body -->
<!-- Optional sections may be omitted. Just remove them or write None -->

<!-- ### Requirements -->
<!-- * Filling out the template is required. Any pull request that does not include enough information to be reviewed in a timely manner may be closed at the maintainers' discretion. -->
<!-- * All new code must have code coverage above 70% (https://docs.codecov.io/docs/about-code-coverage). -->
<!-- * CircleCI builds must be passed. -->
<!-- * Critical and blocker issues reported by Sorabot must be fixed. -->
<!-- * Branch must be rebased onto base branch (https://soramitsu.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/IS/pages/11173889/Rebase+and+merge+guide). -->


### Description of the Change
This PR contains the first attempt to introduce [Hunter](https://docs.hunter.sh/en/latest/) - package manager for CMake projects.
Specifically, it presents Hunter configuration and Boost as the first hunterized dependency.

<!-- We must be able to understand the design of your change from this description. If we can't get a good idea of what the code will be doing from the description here, the pull request may be closed at the maintainers' discretion. -->
<!-- Keep in mind that the maintainer reviewing this PR may not be familiar with or have worked with the code here recently, so please walk us through the concepts. -->

UPD(@warchant): 
- to check that everything works correctly, `build-clean` is added to circle CI.
- cache hunter directory in Circle CI (TODO: upload build artifacts to https://github.com/soramitsu/hunter-binary-cache)



### Benefits
With current `ExternalProject`-based dependency handling we can't get an external project in config time, so we can't guarantee successfulness of its build and even don't know correct paths needed before build-time.
The use of **Hunter** in Iroha building process can sufficiently clarify project dependencies and allow to avoid custom **Find\*.cmake** modules. Also, it has many features like a cache hit, local binary cache, transparent config file that describes dependencies and so on.

<!-- What benefits will be realized by the code change? -->

### Possible Drawbacks 
Despite Hunter in active dev/maintaining stage, it yet another third-party dependency in Iroha on which we will rely. @Warchant have some research about it and team decide to try Hunter on some Iroha dependencies to clarify drawbacks.
Also, we need to think about usage Hunter in the case of making **Shared Model** as separate CMake project. I guess in such case we would need to use Hunter twice.

<!-- What are the possible side-effects or negative impacts of the code change? -->
<!-- If no drawbacks, explicitly mention this (write None) -->

### Usage Examples or Tests *[optional]*

```
cmake -H. -Bbuild
cmake --build build
cmake --build build --target test
```
UPD(@stinger112 27.03.18)
Now Hunter is optional so you must do:
```
cmake -H. -Bbuild -DHUNTER_ENABLED=ON
cmake --build build
cmake --build build --target test
```

### Additional Information
You can check research WIP PR for additional information: #961

title: CI rework
body:
<!-- You will not see HTML commented line in Pull Request body -->
<!-- Optional sections may be omitted. Just remove them or write None -->

<!-- ### Requirements -->
<!-- * Filling out the template is required. Any pull request that does not include enough information to be reviewed in a timely manner may be closed at the maintainers' discretion. -->
<!-- * All new code must have code coverage above 70% (https://docs.codecov.io/docs/about-code-coverage). -->
<!-- * CircleCI builds must be passed. -->
<!-- * Critical and blocker issues reported by Sorabot must be fixed. -->
<!-- * Branch must be rebased onto base branch (https://soramitsu.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/IS/pages/11173889/Rebase+and+merge+guide). -->


### Description of the Change

Significant changes in Jenkinsfile and CI pipeline overall:
- Jenkinsfile is complemented with support for new platforms: armv7, armv8, MacOS
- Debug and Release builds are now separate groovy scripts executed in parallel on different platforms
- Dockerfiles are now compliant with the platform requirements (e.g., armhf version of Docker for armv7). Dockerfiles have also been added with additional packages: newer version of lcov, updated platform detection scripts, Cobertura converter tool
- Docker images stored on Dockerhub are moved to a new repository -- hyperledger/iroha
- Manifest file is created to support multiplatform Docker images (i.e., Docker image can now be simply pulled as `docker pull hyperledger/iroha:latest` or `docker pull hyperledger/iroha:develop` and target platform will be automatically detected. See `docker/manifest.yaml`)
- Introduced options to build bindings. Not working at the moment on all platforms due to environment variables discovery issues (e.g., JAVA_HOME which for some reason is always empty)
- Ansbile inventory is complemented with nodes we are using for running CI pipelines

There are 3 kinds of Docker images this PR implements, distinguished by tags:
- `:develop` -- a Docker image which refers to `develop` branch of this repo and synced to respective Dockerfile (`docker/develop/{platform}/Dockerfile`). Contains the environment and toolkit needed to compile Iroha. Every commit to that branch invokes building of that image and pushing it to Dockerhub.
- `:latest` -- a Docker image which refers to `master` branch of this repo. The DEB package of Iroha is built on every commit to the master branch using `:develop` Docker image and wrapped into a slim image containing a runtime environment only (see `docker/release/{platform}/Dockerfile`)
- `:{platform}-develop-latest` -- a not yet described image in `manifest.yaml` file which is why should be referred by pointing out a target platform for now. A Docker image which refers to `develop` branch of this repo. Works similarly to `:latest` tag but on every commit to develop branch. An image contains installed DEB package of Iroha which is synced with the code in develop branch.

<!-- We must be able to understand the design of your change from this description. If we can't get a good idea of what the code will be doing from the description here, the pull request may be closed at the maintainers' discretion. -->
<!-- Keep in mind that the maintainer reviewing this PR may not be familiar with or have worked with the code here recently, so please walk us through the concepts. -->

### Benefits
- Extended support for platforms we have not tested previously
- Docker manifest file hides differences in platforms

<!-- What benefits will be realized by the code change? -->

### Possible Drawbacks 
- Tests do not support setting Postgres DB name with environment variable. The workaround introduced in this PR is to create separate instance of Postgres listening on different ports. For now this is just a single port 5433 that should not clash with default Postgres port 5432. In case we ever run concurrent builds on a SINGLE Mac machine we should dynamically detect next available port and run separate DB instance on it. It is suggested to add support for passing DB name as an environment variable


<!-- What are the possible side-effects or negative impacts of the code change? -->
<!-- If no drawbacks, explicitly mention this (write None) -->

### Usage Examples or Tests *[optional]*

<!-- Point reviewers to the test, code example or documentation which shows usage example of this feature -->

### Alternate Designs *[optional]*

<!-- Explain what other alternates were considered and why the proposed version was selected -->

title: Fix internal compiler error forever
body:
- set `data seg size` to 3 GB max per terminal
- set `max memory size` to 3 GB max per terminal
- set `virtual memory` to 3 GB  max  per terminal
- set maximum parallelism to 2. Currently we use [`resource_class: medium`](https://circleci.com/docs/2.0/configuration-reference/#resource_class), which is 2 CPUs, 4 GB. 

>Note: A paid account is required to access this feature. Customers on paid plans can request access by opening a support ticket. If resource_class is not specified or an invalid class is specified, the default resource_class: medium will be used. The resource_class key is currently only available for use with the docker executor. 
>Java, Erlang and any other languages that introspect the /proc directory for information about CPU count may require additional configuration to prevent them from slowing down when using the CircleCI 2.0 resource class feature. Programs with this issue may request 32 CPU cores and run slower than they would when requesting one core. Users of languages with this issue should pin their CPU count to their guaranteed CPU resources.

So in this PR I specifically limit parallelism to 2.

3 GB per terminal is selected because I leave 1 GB for OS needs. You can check numbers with `ulimit -a`

Reference: http://www.network-theory.co.uk/docs/gccintro/gccintro_77.html

### Description of the Change

<!-- We must be able to understand the design of your change from this description. If we can't get a good idea of what the code will be doing from the description here, the pull request may be closed at the maintainers' discretion. -->
<!-- Keep in mind that the maintainer reviewing this PR may not be familiar with or have worked with the code here recently, so please walk us through the concepts. -->

- Extract definitions outside of hpp files in `shared_model/cryptography/**/*`. 
- Make cryptography target name `shared_model_cryptography` - neutral to specific algorithm (previous was `shared_model_ed25519_sha3 `)
- Rename `cryptography` target name to `ed25519_crypto` to make it more obvious. `cryptography` is more broad term and covers move than `ed25519_crypto`

### Benefits

<!-- What benefits will be realized by the code change? -->
This change decreases build time and allows further optimizations -- more hpps can be separated onto hpp/cpp (now we get targets, which we can link to), thus decreasing build time and reducing memory consumption during compilation.

<!-- What are the possible side-effects or negative impacts of the code change? -->
<!-- If no drawbacks, explicitly mention this (write None) -->

None.

Fixes bug:

```C++
boost::assign::insert(pb_grant_map_)
    // Can add my signatory
    (protocol::GrantablePermission::can_add_my_signatory,
     can_add_signatory)
    // Can remove my signatory
    (protocol::GrantablePermission::can_remove_my_signatory,
     can_remove_signatory)
    // Can set my quorum
    (protocol::GrantablePermission::can_set_my_quorum, can_set_quorum)
    // Can write details to other accounts
    (protocol::GrantablePermission::can_set_my_account_detail,
     can_set_detail) // ; <-- if ; is here, then next line(s) related to boost::assign::insert are ignored 
    // Can transfer my assets
    (protocol::GrantablePermission::can_transfer_my_assets,
        can_transfer);
```

### Benefits

<!-- What benefits will be realized by the code change? -->

Fix warning at:
```bash
/Users/bogdan/tools/iroha/irohad/model/converters/impl/pb_command_factory.cpp: In constructor 'iroha::model::converters::PbCommandFactory::PbCommandFactory()':
/Users/bogdan/tools/iroha/irohad/model/converters/impl/pb_command_factory.cpp:145:17: error: left operand of comma operator has no effect [-Werror=unused-value]
                 can_transfer);
                 ^~~~~~~~~~~~
```

title: Organize CMake and add Coverage build type
body:
- Organize cmake in a better structure - analysis, config types. Shared model project can re-use that config.
- Add new `CMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=Coverage` -- it installs all necessary flags for coverage and should be used in CI.
- Remove unused fuzzing
- Remove COVERAGE option -- instead, comparison of ${CMAKE_BUILD_TYPE} with `Coverage` can be used.
- Organize flags
- Add ccache support for xcode, ninja, and linker

Same as https://github.com/hyperledger/iroha/pull/983 but without unnecessary changes. All changes are necessary, tested and related to CMake organization.

body:
<!-- You will not see HTML commented line in Pull Request body -->
<!-- Optional sections may be omitted. Just remove them or write None -->

<!-- ### Requirements -->
<!-- * Filling out the template is required. Any pull request that does not include enough information to be reviewed in a timely manner may be closed at the maintainers' discretion. -->

### Description of the Change
At the moment getAccountDetail query unable to request details added by users different from query creator. This pull request changes behaviour of getAccountDetail - now it returns all account details (in JSON format).

<!-- We must be able to understand the design of your change from this description. If we can't get a good idea of what the code will be doing from the description here, the pull request may be closed at the maintainers' discretion. -->
<!-- Keep in mind that the maintainer reviewing this PR may not be familiar with or have worked with the code here recently, so please walk us through the concepts. -->

### Benefits
Possibility to request detail data added from other accounts. Also retrieving a whole details JSON in a single request could be more convenient to clients than to do a request for every key.

<!-- What benefits will be realized by the code change? -->

### Possible Drawbacks 

<!-- What are the possible side-effects or negative impacts of the code change? -->
<!-- If no drawbacks, explicitly mention this (write None) -->
Behaviour of query was changed so old code which uses getAccountDetail becomes broken.

### Usage Examples or Tests *[optional]*
Check kv_storage_test. Also simple example for Java:
In genesis block:
```
{
 "command_type": "SetAccountDetail",
 "account_id": "admin@test",
 "key": "pog",
 "value": "champ"
 }
```
In some .java file:
```
...
UnsignedTx utx = txBuilder.creatorAccountId("admin@test")
            .createdTime(BigInteger.valueOf(currentTime))
            .txCounter(BigInteger.valueOf(startTxCounter))
            .setAccountDetail("admin@test", "lol", "kek")
            .setAccountDetail("admin@test", "kek", "lol")
            .build();
...
UnsignedQuery uquery = queryBuilder.creatorAccountId(creator)
            .queryCounter(BigInteger.valueOf(startQueryCounter))
            .createdTime(BigInteger.valueOf(currentTime))
            .getAccountDetail("admin@test")
            .build();
...
```
Expected result:
```
Query responsed:
Detail = {"genesis": {"pog": "champ"}, "admin@test": {"kek": "lol", "lol": "kek"}}
```

title: ReadTheDocs structure
body:
### Description of the Change

This pull request brings the hierarchy of documentation related to Iroha in order to move forward with the release. Documentation structure was decided in issue #976 and was elaborated in order to fit it better to the project needs.

- Overview section contains project mission, depicts the vision of it, and comparison with other projects.
- Getting started is a short 10-20 minutes guide about how to use Iroha and boost an interest of people in learning or using it.
- Use cases is a discussion about the scenarios, which are suitable for the system so that people can understand where it is used.
- Core concepts explain how the system works in simple words: things like synchronization, consensus, internal schema of objects: this should be told in simple words so that a reader can understand the context better. The glossary is a separate page for every specific terminology used so that it is a central place to review terminology used in the project.
- Guides are how-tos for developers, who are building their applications around Iroha, in a detailed way, but not as detailed as API reference below. Guides answer exact questions and usually are formed to the needs of people, acting as a FAQ catalog.
- API reference is a detailed description of internal and external API used: errors, tx statuses, client libraries interface description, etc.
- Maintenance section is about how to create the environment for Iroha network to be stable, secure and easy to maintain.
- Contribution part explains the community how we work and how they may join the project, what are the communication channels.

Please, before reviewing the pull request check how to build the project locally and try to do it yourself.

### Benefits

In the future, RTD docs are going to be a central place for the public documentation available to everyone. It has versioning, it is widely available and ReStructuredText syntax rocks 🎸 👹 

### Possible Drawbacks 

Now the documentation is not separate from the project, and at some point, it might be a drawback. Also, maybe the theme used is not very cool?

### Usage Examples or Tests *[optional]*

Please open README.MD file in the folder in order to understand how to build the project locally.

### PS

One can find the documentation to be ambiguous, not matching the needs of the project or just dislike it. This is completely fine if the argumentation is clear and addresses real issues, like grammar or logic flaws. Documentation is a weak point now, and the pull request should not be blocked by a long discussion since the structure was already decided in the issue. In the future, corrections are welcome and visual improvements are especially awaited, but for now, let's start with what we have 🙇

title: Update query service
body:
Signed-off-by: kamilsa <kamilsa16@gmail.com>

<!-- You will not see HTML commented line in Pull Request body -->
<!-- Optional sections may be omitted. Just remove them or write None -->

<!-- ### Requirements -->
<!-- * Filling out the template is required. Any pull request that does not include enough information to be reviewed in a timely manner may be closed at the maintainers' discretion. -->
<!-- * All new code must have code coverage above 70% (https://docs.codecov.io/docs/about-code-coverage). -->
<!-- * CircleCI builds must be passed. -->
<!-- * Critical and blocker issues reported by Sorabot must be fixed. -->
<!-- * Branch must be rebased onto base branch (https://soramitsu.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/IS/pages/11173889/Rebase+and+merge+guide). -->


### Description of the Change

QueryService performs redundant operations. Particularly, the following part of the code contained problems:

https://github.com/hyperledger/iroha/blob/def7bc4f7efdf0c2d1c3caecccd2cf3efe0c889e/irohad/torii/impl/query_service.cpp#L53-L77

1. Here on line 60 response's status is set to `STATELESS_INVALID` but this status is not put into cache, whereas response variable is overwritten on line 74 by previous response for the same query hash.
2. On line 64 empty response was put into cache.
3. On line 73 value of optional is taken without checking its existence
4. No tests reflected aforementioned issues
 
### Benefits

All problems above were fixed.

### Possible Drawbacks 

Now if after query is passed into `QueryProcessor::queryHandle` method, but afterwards corresponding query response is not in the cache(empty optional is returned from cache_), query service will return `NOT_SUPPORTED` status.

### Usage Examples or Tests

Tests, reflecting solution of above problems were introduced.

title: Refactor constructors in shared_model/protobuf
body:
<!-- You will not see HTML commented line in Pull Request body -->
<!-- Optional sections may be omitted. Just remove them or write None -->

<!-- ### Requirements -->
<!-- * Filling out the template is required. Any pull request that does not include enough information to be reviewed in a timely manner may be closed at the maintainers' discretion. -->
<!-- * All new code must have code coverage above 70% (https://docs.codecov.io/docs/about-code-coverage). -->
<!-- * CircleCI builds must be passed. -->
<!-- * Critical and blocker issues reported by Sorabot must be fixed. -->
<!-- * Branch must be rebased onto base branch (https://soramitsu.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/IS/pages/11173889/Rebase+and+merge+guide). -->


### Description of the Change

<!-- We must be able to understand the design of your change from this description. If we can't get a good idea of what the code will be doing from the description here, the pull request may be closed at the maintainers' discretion. -->
<!-- Keep in mind that the maintainer reviewing this PR may not be familiar with or have worked with the code here recently, so please walk us through the concepts. -->

Change all constructors in `shared_model/protobuf/*`:

```patch
       explicit AddAssetQuantity(CommandType &&command)
-          : CopyableProto(std::forward<CommandType>(command)),
-            add_asset_quantity_(proto_->add_asset_quantity()),
-            amount_([this] {
-              return proto::Amount(add_asset_quantity_.amount());
-            }) {}
+          : CopyableProto(std::forward<CommandType>(command)) {}

-      const iroha::protocol::AddAssetQuantity &add_asset_quantity_;
+      const iroha::protocol::AddAssetQuantity &add_asset_quantity_{
+          proto_->add_asset_quantity()};
 
-      const Lazy<proto::Amount> amount_;
+      const Lazy<proto::Amount> amount_{
+          [this] { return proto::Amount(add_asset_quantity_.amount()); }};
```

Because of the initialization order:
1) constructors of base classes
2) constructors of derived class
3) members 

It is better to move callbacks to lazy initializers as `non-static data member with initializer`.

It allows to make constructors simpler.

### Benefits

<!-- What benefits will be realized by the code change? -->

This allows me to remove templated constructors (https://soramitsu.atlassian.net/browse/IR-1020) in further optimizations.

All constructors in `shared_model/protobuf/*` now look like
```
template <typename CommandType>
explicit AddAssetQuantity(CommandType &&command)
: CopyableProto(std::forward<CommandType>(command)) {}
``` 

and they can  be easily changed to accept according protocol objects.

### Possible Drawbacks 

<!-- What are the possible side-effects or negative impacts of the code change? -->
<!-- If no drawbacks, explicitly mention this (write None) -->

None.

<!-- We must be able to understand the design of your change from this description. If we can't get a good idea of what the code will be doing from the description here, the pull request may be closed at the maintainers' discretion. -->
<!-- Keep in mind that the maintainer reviewing this PR may not be familiar with or have worked with the code here recently, so please walk us through the concepts. -->

Move `HashType` and `BlobType` from `Hashable` to `common_objects/types.hpp`.

### Benefits

<!-- What benefits will be realized by the code change? -->

Because Hashable is a template, you need weird constructions like https://github.com/hyperledger/iroha/pull/1022/files#diff-f5da1abc9499e5ab936bf6172f85dbb6L71 to actually access the type. Also, what if you want to access this type from some other type, which does not have Hashable as its base class? You simply can't.

Now you can just include header and use it.

### Possible Drawbacks 

<!-- What are the possible side-effects or negative impacts of the code change? -->

None.

title: Pass compiler options and generator
body:
Same as https://github.com/hyperledger/iroha/pull/1009 but:

- changes ed25519 build type from STATIC to SHARED
- adds ed25519 to packaging. 

Because ed25519 is installed as SHARED library in hyperledger/iroha-docker-develop, find_library(ed25519) finds it and sets ed25519_LIBRARY to shared library. Because of this, libed25519.so was not packaged into hyperledger/iroha-docker and it caused run-time error.

This PR fixes this.

title: Clean postgres in ametsuchi test in SetUp
body:
Clean postgres in ametsuchi test in SetUp step, right after connection.

When test dies with SIGSEGV or other error, TearDown is not executed and postgres remains tables and rows, which lead to double insertion of the same primary key (peer id and others).

This PR fixes this.

Example:

body:
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Vaneev <warchantua@gmail.com>

<!-- You will not see HTML commented line in Pull Request body -->
<!-- Optional sections may be omitted. Just remove them or write None -->

<!-- ### Requirements -->
<!-- * Filling out the template is required. Any pull request that does not include enough information to be reviewed in a timely manner may be closed at the maintainers' discretion. -->
<!-- * All new code must have code coverage above 70% (https://docs.codecov.io/docs/about-code-coverage). -->
<!-- * CircleCI builds must be passed. -->
<!-- * Critical and blocker issues reported by Sorabot must be fixed. -->
<!-- * Branch must be rebased onto base branch (https://soramitsu.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/IS/pages/11173889/Rebase+and+merge+guide). -->


### Description of the Change

<!-- We must be able to understand the design of your change from this description. If we can't get a good idea of what the code will be doing from the description here, the pull request may be closed at the maintainers' discretion. -->
<!-- Keep in mind that the maintainer reviewing this PR may not be familiar with or have worked with the code here recently, so please walk us through the concepts. -->
Pass to dependencies:
- compiler generator
- launcher C, CXX (for ccache)
- add gpr lib to packaging, it is used by `grpc`
- remove grpc++_reflection from packaging -- we do not use it.

Change library output path to ${CMAKE_BUILD_DIR} -- means that all external libs will be compiled in `build` directory so we do not need to write full path to these libs.

Fix identations.

**Note**: `iroha_get_lib_name` only does preformatting of library name.
```
Example:
iroha_get_lib_name(OUT iroha SHARED) -> OUT=libiroha.so
iroha_get_lib_name(OUT iroha STATIC) -> OUT=libiroha.a
```

This PR is split part of https://github.com/hyperledger/iroha/pull/983

title: Remove -g flag if coverage is enabled to reduce binary size
body:
Signed-off-by: Andrei Lebedev <lebdron@gmail.com>

<!-- You will not see HTML commented line in Pull Request body -->
<!-- Optional sections may be omitted. Just remove them or write None -->

<!-- ### Requirements -->
<!-- * Filling out the template is required. Any pull request that does not include enough information to be reviewed in a timely manner may be closed at the maintainers' discretion. -->
<!-- * All new code must have code coverage above 70% (https://docs.codecov.io/docs/about-code-coverage). -->
<!-- * CircleCI builds must be passed. -->
<!-- * Critical and blocker issues reported by Sorabot must be fixed. -->
<!-- * Branch must be rebased onto base branch (https://soramitsu.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/IS/pages/11173889/Rebase+and+merge+guide). -->


### Description of the Change
As it was pointed out in https://github.com/hyperledger/iroha/pull/983 , `-g` flag increases binary size, which leads to CircleCI container running out of memory. This pull request removes `-g` flag from coverage builds, allowing CircleCI to pass compilation.
<!-- We must be able to understand the design of your change from this description. If we can't get a good idea of what the code will be doing from the description here, the pull request may be closed at the maintainers' discretion. -->
<!-- Keep in mind that the maintainer reviewing this PR may not be familiar with or have worked with the code here recently, so please walk us through the concepts. -->

### Benefits
CircleCI does not crash with memory error
<!-- What benefits will be realized by the code change? -->

### Possible Drawbacks 
Debugging (for example with gdb) in coverage build is probably not possible due to missing debug information

title: Feature/add custom findswig module
body:
### Description of the Change
This PR introduced customized FindSWIG CMake module. It pulls and builds an appropriate version of SWIG and allow using it in the build system to generate bindings for a target language.

### Benefits
For now, if you want to compile any example or client library for target language you must clone, build, patch and install SWIG manually. Also, you need to choose a particular version of SWIG that supports by the client library. This PR adds more automatization to this process allowing don't have installed version before building the project by CMake.

### Possible Drawbacks 
Every customized module can be hard to maintain because their functionalities mostly based on existing find modules. Also, without tests coverage, it can be hard to check build success on different platforms.
Besides except SWIG library user must install additional dependencies for target language on his system. 

### Usage Examples or Tests
1. Set build configuration (e.g. for *python*)
```
cmake -H. -Bbuild -DSWIG_PYTHON=ON -DSHARED_MODEL_DISABLE_COMPATIBILITY=ON
```
2. Build project. It starts cloning and building SWIG
```
cmake --build build/ --target irohapy -- -j"$(getconf _NPROCESSORS_ONLN)"
```

### Additional Information
Local SWIG installed in `<project_root>/external/src/swig_swig`. We can use this installation in `prepare.sh` scripts of different examples.

title: Fix Circle CI
body:
This PR fixes three issues in Circle CI:
- Internal  compiler error
- Ccache will work correctly after this PR
    - Cache sizes: Debug (1 build ~2G), Release Linux (~100M), Release Mac (~30M)
    - circle ci can not evaluate $CCACHE_DIR variable in yaml file and it resulted in disabling ccache
- circle ci can not evaluate $SONAR_DIR in yaml, and it resulted in cache miss

title: Fix -Wreturn-type
body:
Because function returns `template V` (some object) and does not return anything, it caused warning, which in turn, with -Werror resulted in compilation error.

UPD: when you use BOOST_ASSERT in such function, and program is compiled with -DNDEBUG (any release mode), it actually disables BOOST_ASSERT and warning `-Wreturn-type` appears.

title: Shared Model Primitive Builders
body:
Signed-off-by: Nikita Alekseev <n.alekseev2104@gmail.com>

### Description of the Change

This PR introduces builders for shared_model primitive objects such as Account, Peer etc.

There are currently 2 types of builders - common builder, which performs validation and returns interfaces, and concrete builders (currently protobuf ones), which create a specific implementation of an object for given shared_model implementation.

Common builders are parametrized by a concrete builder so that you can select implementation of your interfaces and mock concrete builders.

### Benefits

This introduces a safe way to construct basic shared_model objects and can be used when we want to instantiate these objects from arbitrary data, such as after taking them from the database.
<!-- What benefits will be realized by the code change? -->

### Possible Drawbacks 

Increased complexity
<!-- What are the possible side-effects or negative impacts of the code change? -->
<!-- If no drawbacks, explicitly mention this (write None) -->

### Usage Examples or Tests *[optional]*

Builder usage should be intuitive since it is a pretty common design pattern. Test examples can be seen in corresponding directories.

### Alternate Designs *[optional]*

Instead of template parametrization, inheritance could be used, where we either inject implementation or just provide a pure virtual interface for builders. However dynamic polymorphism is not useful here, since dynamic dispatch is not needed, and templates, allow us to use specific builders as well as common ones interchangeably.
<!-- Explain what other alternates were considered and why the proposed version was selected -->

### Description of the Change

This package will let you publish the latest iroha binaries in the Ubuntu store, and from there reach many users on all the supported Ubuntu versions, and Linux distributions. You just have to go to https://build.snapcraft.io and enable the automated continuous delivery. 
<!-- We must be able to understand the design of your change from this description. If we can't get a good idea of what the code will be doing from the description here, the pull request may be closed at the maintainers' discretion. -->
<!-- Keep in mind that the maintainer reviewing this PR may not be familiar with or have worked with the code here recently, so please walk us through the concepts. -->

### Benefits
1-command installs, complete isolation when the snap is made strict, automatic updates, 4 channels with different levels of risks to make things easy and fun for your testers.

### Possible Drawbacks 

At this point, none. You can just give it a try in edge, and see if you like it before publishing it to stable. Once it's in stable, you will get users and will have to keep moving the releases from the edge channel when they are ready.

title: [WIP] Hunterize iroha
body:
# Motivation
Current approach with dependencies is bad, because we are forced to hardcode paths for libs and include headers. This is error prone is some toolchains, such as XCode, which we need to support.
The solution we've selected is [Hunter](https://github.com/ruslo/hunter) -- CMake-only script, which manages all dependencies in configuration time.

# Comments

- **This trunk and PR is used to test CI and keep track of progress**. 
- **do not push directly to this branch**, only via PRs. 

After we finish hunterization of all dependencies, we will forget about headache with them forever.
This is a good way to manage dependencies and good chance to upgrade their versions to the latest.

# Current state

This branch will be used as trunk. This trunk will be merged into develop as soon as all dependencies will be hunterized. 

Please do not update the following list by yourself. It helps to keep track of tasks required to finish migration to Hunter.

List of dependencies. (x - hunterized, empty - not hunterized)
- [ ] protobuf
- [ ] postgresql + pqxx
- [ ] grpc
- [x] rapidjson 1.1.0
- [x] boost 1.65.1
    - [x] filesystem
    - [x] system
    - [ ] spirit
- [x] gtest and gmock 1.8.0
- [ ] gflags 2.2 - needs to be tested, may be buggy, so probably we will need to hunterize different version.
- [ ] c-ares
- [x] spdlog 0.13 -- but we need 0.16, so we need to hunterize new version.
- [ ] rxcpp
- [ ] ed25519 -- repository hyperledger/iroha-ed25519 is ready to be hunterized
- [ ] tbb
- [ ] optional (martinmoene)
- [ ] swig
- [ ] google benchmark

Also, all CI systems and scripts should be cleaned and fixed:
- [ ] CircleCI
- [ ] Jenkins

# Other changes

- organize cmake files and scripts in better structure
- add new configuration type `-DCMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=Coverage`, which adds necessary flags to collect more quality coverage metrics
- add ccache support for XCode
- add hunter binary cache: 
    Now you can specify 2 environment variables: `GITHUB_USER` with your username and `GITHUB_USER_PASSWORD` with your personal access token with permission `public_repo`, then specify `cmake .. -DHUNTER_RUN_UPLOAD=ON` and it will download, build and upload binary files to https://github.com/soramitsu/hunter-binary-cache . Cache hit will be if and only if hunter version, toolchain and architecture are same.
- fix bug in `clang-format` target: it fixed by mistake all files inside `external` directory.
- update minimal required cmake to 3.7

title: Fix flags in cmake
body:
This fix adds caching for default flags, so now it is possible to set them in cmake time.

Before:
```
cmake -DCMAKE_CXX_FLAGS="-O3" ..
```
will be overwritten with `set(CMAKE_CXX_FLAGS "...")

Now -- CMAKE_CXX_FLAGS will be cached from cmake arguments.

Compiling spdlog in alpine environment becomes possible.

title: Rework OrderingService with new model
body:
### Description of the Change

Change OrderingServices' interfaces to the new shared model

### Issues

There's some issues that've been solved as simple as possible, though it's probably not really a good solution

#### iface -> proto

There's need to convert `proto::Proposal` to `protocol::Proposal`, it's pretty easy to set all the fields via builder but transactions. SM's proposal returns an interface, so there's no simple way to convert to protobuf, so I just use `makeOldModel` + `from_old`:

https://github.com/hyperledger/iroha/blob/5b711d1d7348f853ab8cda74e4b5b87207a24198/irohad/ordering/impl/ordering_service_transport_grpc.cpp#L61-L71

#### Pretty hard to create a simple tx

I guess the example is self-explainable

https://github.com/hyperledger/iroha/blob/5b711d1d7348f853ab8cda74e4b5b87207a24198/test/module/irohad/ordering/ordering_service_test.cpp#L82-L89

#### tbb queue wrapper

The tbb's concurrent queue can't work with interfaces (and even with `unique_ptr`), so I just used `shared_ptr` instead. Imo that can be a significant performance issue

https://github.com/hyperledger/iroha/blob/5b711d1d7348f853ab8cda74e4b5b87207a24198/irohad/ordering/impl/ordering_service_impl.hpp#L94

title: Fix/nptr to result
body:
<!-- You will not see HTML commented line in Pull Request body -->
<!-- Optional sections may be omitted. Just remove them or write None -->

<!-- ### Requirements -->
<!-- * Filling out the template is required. Any pull request that does not include enough information to be reviewed in a timely manner may be closed at the maintainers' discretion. -->
<!-- * All new code must have code coverage above 70% (https://docs.codecov.io/docs/about-code-coverage). -->
<!-- * CircleCI builds must be passed. -->
<!-- * Critical and blocker issues reported by Sorabot must be fixed. -->
<!-- * Branch must be rebased onto base branch (https://soramitsu.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/IS/pages/11173889/Rebase+and+merge+guide). -->


### Description of the Change

A bad thing about smart pointers is they may store nullptr. In project we may guarantee that smart pointer has valid value inside. For purposes where there is no guarantee we should change type to Result<smart_pointer, error>. And this type explicitly say that there is possible null value.

This Pr fixes the problem above in /iroha/irohad/ametsuchi/impl/storage_impl.cpp

### Benefits

null pointers are explicitly processed

### Possible Drawbacks 

in several places, auto type deduction can't be used as
`auto p = ...` is substituted with `type p; match([]() { p = ... }) `

title: Torii streaming
body:
<!-- You will not see HTML commented line in Pull Request body -->
<!-- Optional sections may be omitted. Just remove them or write None -->

<!-- ### Requirements -->
<!-- * Filling out the template is required. Any pull request that does not include enough information to be reviewed in a timely manner may be closed at the maintainers' discretion. -->
<!-- * All new code must have code coverage above 70% (https://docs.codecov.io/docs/about-code-coverage). -->
<!-- * CircleCI builds must be passed. -->
<!-- * Critical and blocker issues reported by Sorabot must be fixed. -->
<!-- * Branch must be rebased onto base branch (https://soramitsu.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/IS/pages/11173889/Rebase+and+merge+guide). -->


### Description of the Change

<!-- We must be able to understand the design of your change from this description. If we can't get a good idea of what the code will be doing from the description here, the pull request may be closed at the maintainers' discretion. -->
<!-- Keep in mind that the maintainer reviewing this PR may not be familiar with or have worked with the code here recently, so please walk us through the concepts. -->

Streaming grpc call for transaction statuses.

### Benefits

<!-- What benefits will be realized by the code change? -->
We want to have a push-based notifications for tx statuses so here we are.

### Possible Drawbacks 

<!-- What are the possible side-effects or negative impacts of the code change? -->
<!-- If no drawbacks, explicitly mention this (write None) -->
Each streaming call can theoretically block one of grpc thread up to a second. This timeout can be decreased in a least 10 times but it allows to start streaming call before transaction sending.

### Usage Examples or Tests *[optional]*

<!-- Point reviewers to the test, code example or documentation which shows usage example of this feature -->
Two tests were added to torii_service_test.

### Alternate Designs *[optional]*

<!-- Explain what other alternates were considered and why the proposed version was selected -->
Two main possibilities were checked: use combined Torii request which will return stream of responses or use separate calls for that (the second one was actually implemented). The first approach was faced with thread-related difficulties (kick me and I explain details).

title: Add multisig integration test
body:
### Description of the Change

Test for multisignature module. It has checking that the tx comes to the commit after all signers sign it 



### Usage Examples or Tests

`make multisig_tx_pipeline_test && test_bin/multisig_tx_pipeline_test`

### Alternate Designs

There's issue with the command_service: it caches the same txes, so I add a pass for mst txes, that may be not really good idea.

This will going to be reworked with new ITF, look at the [`feature/mst-integration`](https://github.com/hyperledger/iroha/tree/feature/mst-integration) if you're interested

title: WsvCommand returns result instead of optional
body:
### Description of the Change
This change is one of the several changes to provide better error messages to end users and developers. It does so by introducing Result class to PostgresWsvCommand, which allows us to specify what exactly went wrong during execution of the command.


### Benefits
1. Better error messages, in case any Postgres command fails
2. Cleaner code in command_executor

### Possible Drawbacks 

1. Queries still return optional, so code is inconsistent.
2. Increased size of the postgres_wsv_command
3. More tests need to be added to verify error messages
<!-- What are the possible side-effects or negative impacts of the code change? -->
<!-- If no drawbacks, explicitly mention this (write None) -->

title: Fix issues found by cppclean in libs, iroha-cli, irohad/ametsuchi, irohad/consensus
body:
<!-- You will not see HTML commented line in Pull Request body -->
<!-- Optional sections may be omitted. Just remove them or write None -->

<!-- ### Requirements -->
<!-- * Filling out the template is required. Any pull request that does not include enough information to be reviewed in a timely manner may be closed at the maintainers' discretion. -->
<!-- * All new code must have code coverage above 70% (https://docs.codecov.io/docs/about-code-coverage). -->
<!-- * CircleCI builds must be passed. -->
<!-- * Critical and blocker issues reported by Sorabot must be fixed. -->
<!-- * Branch must be rebased onto base branch (https://soramitsu.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/IS/pages/11173889/Rebase+and+merge+guide). -->


### Description of the Change

<!-- We must be able to understand the design of your change from this description. If we can't get a good idea of what the code will be doing from the description here, the pull request may be closed at the maintainers' discretion. -->
<!-- Keep in mind that the maintainer reviewing this PR may not be familiar with or have worked with the code here recently, so please walk us through the concepts. -->

cppclean has found many issues (https://hackmd.io/IYTmBNwRmAGBaATANgOwICzIMaPgDgDMBWBfbYDAI1gGZbgrFag=?view). 

I spent around 6-7 hours to fix some. Here is the result: https://hackmd.io/KYNgrAjGDMAmDGBaUxiICwCYAMtEA5tp9EBDdAMxwCMBOCbMeCoA?view


Here is the diff:
https://www.diffchecker.com/Nl5cxDew

You may notice that some new issues are added, but do not worry, many of them are false-positives and there are no other way to fix the issue.

It is the first PR in series of PRs, which fix all problems.

Here I fixed only:
- iroha-cli
- libs
- ametsuchi
- consensus


### Benefits

<!-- What benefits will be realized by the code change? -->

This PR does not change any logic, it introduces only small code refactorings.

Generally cppclean looks for unused includes, or suggests to place forward declarations. Both of these techniques reduce interdependency between objects, which is good -- it reduces recompilation of targets, if certain headers are changed.

Also, it found functions defined in cpp without keyword `static`. Without this keyword, functions have `external linkage` by default and are accessible by the rest of program just through forward declaration. I fixed also this.

### Possible Drawbacks 

<!-- What are the possible side-effects or negative impacts of the code change? -->
<!-- If no drawbacks, explicitly mention this (write None) -->

There are many issues with logger. Because logger is an alias to `spdlog::logger`, I need to write many lines to write forward declaration, which is bad. 
If we really need to fix these issues, I suggest to remove `logger::Logger` and use `std::unique_ptr<stdlog::logger>` everywhere. For now logger introduces many false positives.

<!-- * Branch must be rebased onto base branch (https://soramitsu.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/IS/pages/11173889/Rebase+and+merge+guide). -->


### Description of the Change

<!-- We must be able to understand the design of your change from this description. If we can't get a good idea of what the code will be doing from the description here, the pull request may be closed at the maintainers' discretion. -->
<!-- Keep in mind that the maintainer reviewing this PR may not be familiar with or have worked with the code here recently, so please walk us through the concepts. -->

- Easy way to register Torii services
- Use sync server implementation instead of async
- Remove async implemenation

### Benefits

- Way easier to add new Torii services
- Less code
- Simple code (sync server significantly easier to write and support)
- Grpc manages thread poll/message queues/etc bu itself

### Possible Drawbacks 

<!-- What are the possible side-effects or negative impacts of the code change? -->
<!-- If no drawbacks, explicitly mention this (write None) -->
- Services still aware about transport (subject for another task and another PR)

### Usage Examples or Tests *[optional]*

<!-- Point reviewers to the test, code example or documentation which shows usage example of this feature -->

To add a new Torii service:
- Add its description to proto file
- Inherit you service implementation class from iroha::protocol::<service_name>::Service and implement all methods you need by overriding grpc stubs
- Create your service class instance in application.cpp and add it to services collection, like
```torii_services.emplace_back(std::move(<your_service>));```
- Enjoy your service working

title: Test builders
body:
<!-- You will not see HTML commented line in Pull Request body -->
<!-- Optional sections may be omitted. Just remove them or write None -->

<!-- ### Requirements -->
<!-- * Filling out the template is required. Any pull request that does not include enough information to be reviewed in a timely manner may be closed at the maintainers' discretion. -->
<!-- * All new code must have code coverage above 70% (https://docs.codecov.io/docs/about-code-coverage). -->
<!-- * CircleCI builds must be passed. -->
<!-- * Critical and blocker issues reported by Sorabot must be fixed. -->
<!-- * Branch must be rebased onto base branch (https://soramitsu.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/IS/pages/11173889/Rebase+and+merge+guide). -->


### Description of the Change

1. Adds test builders for transaction and query creation. 
2. Creates two new validators to query and transaction which always return empty answer with no errors (for test purposes)
3. Introduces new template parameter to query and transaction builder defining build type of the builder
4. Moves template tx and query builders into separate folders. Now transaction and query builders have only using definitions inside

### Benefits

Now we can build any transaction or query shared model objects using new builders, which has similar interfaces with the real builders

<!-- What benefits will be realized by the code change? -->

### Possible Drawbacks 

Unfortunately, we cannot use mocks to replace validators in tests because of drawback of google mock classes -- they cannot be copied. That prevents using them in builders, because every time we add new command to transaction we internally copy builder object, which is not possible when we use mock as stateless validator field.

<!-- What are the possible side-effects or negative impacts of the code change? -->
<!-- If no drawbacks, explicitly mention this (write None) -->

### Usage Examples or Tests

```C++
#include "test_builder.hpp"
...
shared_model::interface::types::CounterType tx_counter = 1;
std::string creator_account_id = "admin@test";

TestTransactionBuilder builder;
auto tx = builder.txCounter(tx_counter)
                  .creatorAccountId(creator_account_id)
                  .createdTime(created_time)
                  .build()
```

title: Command Executor returns error message on execute()
body:
### Description of the Change

This pull request modifies execute() method in command_executor, to return Result instead of bool. This means, that if for some reason, execution of the command has failed, a caller of the executor will know the reason why. This allows for better informativeness of error messages.
<!-- We must be able to understand the design of your change from this description. If we can't get a good idea of what the code will be doing from the description here, the pull request may be closed at the maintainers' discretion. -->
<!-- Keep in mind that the maintainer reviewing this PR may not be familiar with or have worked with the code here recently, so please walk us through the concepts. -->

### Benefits
1. Command executor now returns meaningful error message
2. Returned error contains command name

<!-- What benefits will be realized by the code change? -->

### Possible Drawbacks 
1. Validate still returns bool, so it is impossible to know if the database has failed during validation.
2. Because database operations still return boolean, or optional, a lot of code needs to be added to transform it into the result, in the future, it will be simplified.
<!-- What are the possible side-effects or negative impacts of the code change? -->
<!-- If no drawbacks, explicitly mention this (write None) -->

### Usage Examples or Tests *[optional]*
Mutable storage and temporary wsv both output error message from command_executor into the log. This is the simplest use, and they can return a result as well, to tell components up in the chain what happened.
<!-- Point reviewers to the test, code example or documentation which shows usage example of this feature -->

https://github.com/hyperledger/iroha/blob/4e58f7780b8c918e56328231ec8f5a9fd67bb429/shared_model/builders/protobuf/transaction.hpp#L211-L215

That's pr updates old model permission string names, so it may work with the shared_model as well.

### Possible Drawbacks 

?

### Alternate Designs

As an additional way of fixing that is converting permissions and leaving the old model as is. Imo that not really good because it requires update such strings in multiple places.

title: Feature/replace flat file with nudb
body:
### Description of the Change

- [x] remove flat_file implementation
- [x] preserve flat_file.hpp interface in block_storage.hpp
- [x] make block_storage.hpp pure virtual class
- [x] split block_query_test onto two tests:  
       - unit test: uses mock for block  storage
       - integration test: uses NuDB underneath
- [x] implement block_storage.hpp interface with NuDB
- [x] remove `last_id` from block_storage.hpp, because logically it is invalid. Instead, add `total_keys` method.
- [x] update `hyperledger/iroha-docker-develop` to `v2` - it has new CMake (3.10.2), more boost libraries (thread, chrono, program_options), integrated NuDB
- [x] fix all tests, few minor bugs and miss spellings

### Benefits

- new cmake version in develop image
- new implementation of Block Storage with use of NuDB
- now Block Storage stores blocks properly, from index #0

### Possible Drawbacks 

- NuDB is bad option to store blocks and must be considered as short-term solution.
- BlockStorage interface must be reviewed and redesigned with use of cryptography (to have a possibility to implement light clients)
- BlockStorage now has no block validation logic. I.e., when you open database first time, you need to check that all stored blocks are really blocks, have valid signatures, and re-build WSV (or check its consistency, TBD) 

### Usage Examples or Tests *[optional]*

- [./test/module/vendor/nudb_usage.cpp](./test/module/vendor/nudb_usage.cpp)


### Alternate Designs *[optional]*

https://github.com/hyperledger/iroha/issues/774
