body:
Signed-off-by: kamilsa <kamilsa16@gmail.com>

<!-- You will not see HTML commented line in Pull Request body -->
<!-- Optional sections may be omitted. Just remove them or write None -->

<!-- ### Requirements -->
<!-- * Filling out the template is required. Any pull request that does not include enough information to be reviewed in a timely manner may be closed at the maintainers' discretion. -->
<!-- * All new code must have code coverage above 70% (https://docs.codecov.io/docs/about-code-coverage). -->
<!-- * CircleCI builds must be passed. -->
<!-- * Critical and blocker issues reported by Sorabot must be fixed. -->
<!-- * Branch must be rebased onto base branch (https://soramitsu.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/IS/pages/11173889/Rebase+and+merge+guide). -->


### Description of the Change
Adds json converters from shared model objects with proto backend. 

### Benefits

Allows converting shared model objects into json and vice versa by means of protobuf methods.

### Possible Drawbacks 

* Currently conversions are done using functions without classes. Might look as a drawback for someone.

* While model to json function is straightforward, conversion from command contains 3 functions: 
1. jsonToModel -- general function to convert json into protobuf message objects. Returns none if json is not valid.
2. jsonToBlock -- function converting json into shared model block. Returns none if json is not valid.
3. jsonToTransaction -- function converting json into shared model transaction. Returns none if json is not valid.

* At the moment this PR was implemented proto class for proposal was not implemented. In future jsonToProposal function might be included.

### Usage Examples or Tests *[optional]*

Tests were added.

title: Fix/cli new acc
body:
### Description of the Change

- Add separation of KeysManager's create/load methods that work with and without pass phrase
- Key is randomly generated
- Pass phrase now is used for encryption/decryption (for now pretty dummy xor) of the private key on the disk (can be empty, then stored as plain text)
- Add some related tests

### Benefits

No guessable keys, more clear iface for KeysManager

### Possible Drawbacks 

Key can be lost and there's no way of reverting it back

### Usage Examples or Tests *[optional]*

```bash
# saves plain text keys
iroha-cli --new_account --name test@acc

# saves plain text public key and encrypted private key
iroha-cli --new_account --name test@acc --pass_phrase 12345
```
### TODO so far

- Create key file structure
- Replace encryption scheme

title: Result Type
body:
<!-- You will not see HTML commented line in Pull Request body -->
<!-- Optional sections may be omitted. Just remove them or write None -->

<!-- ### Requirements -->
<!-- * Filling out the template is required. Any pull request that does not include enough information to be reviewed in a timely manner may be closed at the maintainers' discretion. -->
<!-- * All new code must have code coverage above 70% (https://docs.codecov.io/docs/about-code-coverage). -->
<!-- * CircleCI builds must be passed. -->
<!-- * Critical and blocker issues reported by Sorabot must be fixed. -->
<!-- * Branch must be rebased onto base branch (https://soramitsu.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/IS/pages/11173889/Rebase+and+merge+guide). -->


### Description of the Change
Based on https://github.com/hyperledger/iroha/pull/603, this pull request introduces Resutl<V, E> type which is either a result or an error. It can be used in error handling as a replacement for exceptions, where failure is expected, for example, validation, database access.

### Benefits

1. Allows providing information about error (one of the main drawbacks of optional)
2. More performant than exception handling and does not complicate control flow

### Possible Drawbacks 

1. Functional style match() call is used to retrieve a value, and any other option is no available. It disallows writing procedural style code.

<!-- What are the possible side-effects or negative impacts of the code change? -->
<!-- If no drawbacks, explicitly mention this (write None) -->

### Usage Examples or Tests *[optional]*
Usage examples are provided in code comments

### Alternate Designs *[optional]*
Instead of match(), various utility functions such as value(), has_value() could be provided, but they encourage writing a lot of boilerplate code, and make code such as Result<bool, ...> too easy to use incorrectly.

title: Use rttr for cpp reflection
body:
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Vaneev <warchantua@gmail.com>

<!-- You will not see HTML commented line in Pull Request body -->
<!-- Optional sections may be omitted. Just remove them or write None -->

<!-- ### Requirements -->
<!-- * Filling out the template is required. Any pull request that does not include enough information to be reviewed in a timely manner may be closed at the maintainers' discretion. -->
<!-- * All new code must have code coverage above 70% (https://docs.codecov.io/docs/about-code-coverage). -->
<!-- * CircleCI builds must be passed. -->
<!-- * Critical and blocker issues reported by Sorabot must be fixed. -->
<!-- * Branch must be rebased onto base branch (https://soramitsu.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/IS/pages/11173889/Rebase+and+merge+guide). -->


### Description of the Change

<!-- We must be able to understand the design of your change from this description. If we can't get a good idea of what the code will be doing from the description here, the pull request may be closed at the maintainers' discretion. -->
<!-- Keep in mind that the maintainer reviewing this PR may not be familiar with or have worked with the code here recently, so please walk us through the concepts. -->

- [x] Integrate [`warchant/rttr`](https://github.com/warchant/rttr) - I had to fork it to fix few bugs related to installation of the library on Linux/Mac machines
- [x] Update develop Dockerfile
- [x] Update `hyperledger/iroha-docker-develop` from `v1` to `v2`
- [x] Add simple test.

### Benefits

<!-- What benefits will be realized by the code change? -->

This PR introduces C++ Runtime Reflection library. It can be used to write tests for repetitive objects, like commands, queries - etc.

### Possible Drawbacks 

<!-- What are the possible side-effects or negative impacts of the code change? -->
<!-- If no drawbacks, explicitly mention this (write None) -->

I tested `Findrttr.cmake` locally on MAC, in docker, with or without lib. However, it is possible that script isn't perfect. Also, library seems good but sometimes it may give you a surprise. Be careful. But it is still the best option. 

### Usage Examples or Tests *[optional]*

<!-- Point reviewers to the test, code example or documentation which shows usage example of this feature -->

[test_reflection.cpp](test/framework/test_reflection.cpp)
Documentation: http://www.rttr.org/doc/master/five_minute_tutorial_page.html

### Alternate Designs *[optional]*

<!-- Explain what other alternates were considered and why the proposed version was selected -->

- https://github.com/Manu343726/siplasplas - this project offers simple cmake-time clang-based reflection system. I was unable to build it, however I was able to use precompiled distribution from releases. It works only in docker. Branch: https://github.com/hyperledger/iroha/tree/feature/cppreflection
- https://github.com/AustinBrunkhorst/CPP-Reflection - it also offers simple cmake-time clang- based reflection system. Again, I was unable to build it completely. I did not manage to build/run/test this library due to dependency hell.
- https://github.com/Cylix/Reflex - library provides in-place macroses, which can be used for reflection. Syntax looks worse than rttr. 
- https://github.com/billyquith/ponder - pretty much the same as `rttr`. Older. Not as active, as `rttr`.

title: Feature/refactor cli default peer
body:
### Description of the Change

Refactor iroha-cli by introducing a default peer. Add more verbose description to flags.  

### Benefits

Easier interaction with the system as you do not need to type in peer address every time.  
iroha-cli runs with peer_ip and torii_port flags (by default 0.0.0.0 and 50051). 
In interactive mode when sending to iroha default value will be displayed in parentheses.

### Possible Drawbacks 
None

title: Ansible rewrite + Jenkins pipeline
body:
<!-- You will not see HTML commented line in Pull Request body -->
<!-- Optional sections may be omitted. Just remove them or write None -->

<!-- ### Requirements -->
<!-- * Filling out the template is required. Any pull request that does not include enough information to be reviewed in a timely manner may be closed at the maintainers' discretion. -->
<!-- * All new code must have code coverage above 70% (https://docs.codecov.io/docs/about-code-coverage). -->
<!-- * CircleCI builds must be passed. -->
<!-- * Critical and blocker issues reported by Sorabot must be fixed. -->
<!-- * Branch must be rebased onto base branch (https://soramitsu.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/IS/pages/11173889/Rebase+and+merge+guide). -->


### Description of the Change
#### Ansible
Ansible playbook was rewritten from scratch. There are now two separate roles for setting up Iroha cluster of arbitrary number of nodes, plus docker daemon installation routine.
A general role for user creation is also added.

#### Jenkins
Initial support for Jenkins pipeline introduced. All the steps except "dockerize" are reproduced.
<!-- We must be able to understand the design of your change from this description. If we can't get a good idea of what the code will be doing from the description here, the pull request may be closed at the maintainers' discretion. -->
<!-- Keep in mind that the maintainer reviewing this PR may not be familiar with or have worked with the code here recently, so please walk us through the concepts. -->

### Benefits
As Ansible playbooks are now modular, further maintenance becomes less tedious and error prone.
With Jenkins introduction, we expect the builds to be more customizable.

title: Delete legacy docs and add new project for reStructuredText
body:
### Description of the Change

The purpose of this documentation is to convey design and architecure aspects of Iroha ledger in a sctructured approach, as well as operational side: how-tos, guides, and examples. Docs are accessible via ReadTheDocs website, and can be generated to a lot of formats, available in Sphinx. In order to contribute, one should to be familiar with [reStructuredTest](docutils.sourceforge.net/rst.html) syntax, and follow principles described in this file.

### Benefits

Deleted legacy, created a structure for docs and example of docs, including launching Iroha on single node.

### Possible Drawbacks 

Requires constant updates of docs, and administering project in ReadTheDocs.

### Usage Examples or Tests *[optional]*

 * Python 2.7 installed
 * `pip install -r requirements.txt` in docs/source

Build steps

1. `cd docs/source`
1. `make html`

After that, the documentation is generated in html format in `_build` folder. You can check another formats on Sphinx website or just by typing `make`.

### Description of the Change

<!-- We must be able to understand the design of your change from this description. If we can't get a good idea of what the code will be doing from the description here, the pull request may be closed at the maintainers' discretion. -->

This pull request fixes memory leaks in torii_service_test, torii_queries_test and client_test.

### Benefits

<!-- What benefits will be realized by the code change? -->
Well, leaks are bad ;)

### Possible Drawbacks 

<!-- What are the possible side-effects or negative impacts of the code change? -->
<!-- If no drawbacks, explicitly mention this (write None) -->
Probably none (I hope)

### Usage Examples or Tests *[optional]*

<!-- Point reviewers to the test, code example or documentation which shows usage example of this feature -->
Build project with ```-fsanitize=address``` and run tests as ```ASAN_OPTIONS=detect_leaks=1 ctest```:
```
90% tests passed, 8 tests failed out of 78

Total Test time (real) =  39.61 sec

The following tests FAILED:
	  3 - ametsuchi_test (Child aborted)
	  4 - wsv_query_command_test (Failed)
	 15 - yac_timer_test (Child aborted)
	 47 - ordering_service_test (Child aborted)
	 49 - ordering_gate_service_test (Child aborted)
	 73 - field_validator_test (Failed)
	 77 - tx_pipeline_integration_test (Child aborted)
	 78 - transfer_asset_inter_domain_test (Child aborted)
```
Without current fix 11 tests will fail.

### P.S.
Please note change in ServerRunner destructor - it doesn't call shutdown for toriiServiceHandler anymore. The reason for that is possible double delete problem because ServerRunner::shutdown also also calls shutdown for toriiServiceHandler.

title: Feature/yac order impl
body:
<!-- You will not see HTML commented line in Pull Request body -->
<!-- Optional sections may be omitted. Just remove them or write None -->

<!-- ### Requirements -->
<!-- * Filling out the template is required. Any pull request that does not include enough information to be reviewed in a timely manner may be closed at the maintainers' discretion. -->
<!-- * All new code must have code coverage above 70% (https://docs.codecov.io/docs/about-code-coverage). -->
<!-- * CircleCI builds must be passed. -->
<!-- * Critical and blocker issues reported by Sorabot must be fixed. -->
<!-- * Branch must be rebased onto base branch (https://soramitsu.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/IS/pages/11173889/Rebase+and+merge+guide). -->


### Description of the Change

<!-- We must be able to understand the design of your change from this description. If we can't get a good idea of what the code will be doing from the description here, the pull request may be closed at the maintainers' discretion. -->
<!-- Keep in mind that the maintainer reviewing this PR may not be familiar with or have worked with the code here recently, so please walk us through the concepts. -->
YAC relies on uniform peer order distribution for leaders selection, provided by getOrdering function.     
In this pr we implement pseudorandom ordering function which returns peer order uniformly distributed depending on the hash of the block.  

### Benefits

It is harder for adversary  to attack rotating leader committee. 

### Possible Drawbacks 

Current implementation relies on default random generation engine based on http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/numeric/random/linear_congruential_engine. 

<!-- What are the possible side-effects or negative impacts of the code change? -->
<!-- If no drawbacks, explicitly mention this (write None) -->

### Usage Examples or Tests *[optional]*

A toy test for a fairness of distribution is in this pr.  A simple statistic for distribution test can be considered in future, like https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kolmogorov–Smirnov_test 
<!-- Point reviewers to the test, code example or documentation which shows usage example of this feature -->

### Alternate Designs *[optional]*

It is interesting to implement for the future alternative order function with exponential distribution depending on various statistics, like availability time, probability of maliciousness etc. 
     
<!-- Explain what other alternates were considered and why the proposed version was selected -->

title: Replace make with $(MAKE) in cmake
body:
`make -j<n>` leads to:

```
[ 28%] Performing build step for 'jtv_libpqxx'
make[3]: warning: jobserver unavailable: using -j1.  Add '+' to parent make rule.
```

So this fix basically replaces `make` with with `$(MAKE)` in __cmake/Modules/Find*.cmake__ files according to [this discussion](http://cmake.3232098.n2.nabble.com/How-would-I-use-parallel-make-on-ExternalProjects-td5609078.html)

<!-- We must be able to understand the design of your change from this description. If we can't get a good idea of what the code will be doing from the description here, the pull request may be closed at the maintainers' discretion. -->

This PR adds bash script `scripts/local-develop.sh`, which, when executed, creates two docker containers `<postgres, redis>` and outputs according environment variables. These can be safely used to execute your tests without docker environment.

Also I added +x permission for `scripts/build-test-swarm.sh`.

### Benefits

<!-- What benefits will be realized by the code change? -->
Using this script bootstrapping of test/dev environment is easy.

### Possible Drawbacks 

<!-- What are the possible side-effects or negative impacts of the code change? -->
<!-- If no drawbacks, explicitly mention this (write None) -->
None.

### Usage Examples or Tests *[optional]*

<!-- Point reviewers to the test, code example or documentation which shows usage example of this feature -->
```bash
$ source scripts/local-develop.sh
# stderr
postgres: 127.0.0.1:5432 {login: postgres, pwd: mysecretpassword}
redis:    127.0.0.1:6379
# stdout
export IROHA_POSTGRES_HOST=127.0.0.1
export IROHA_POSTGRES_PORT=5432
export IROHA_POSTGRES_USER=postgres
export IROHA_POSTGRES_DATABASE=postgres
export IROHA_POSTGRES_PASSWORD=mysecretpassword
export IROHA_REDIS_HOST=127.0.0.1
export IROHA_REDIS_PORT=6379
```

You can easily setup your CLion with these variables to execute/debug tests locally, without docker.


### Alternate Designs *[optional]*

<!-- Explain what other alternates were considered and why the proposed version was selected -->

None.

title: Improve stateless validation
body:
<!-- You will not see HTML commented line in Pull Request body -->
<!-- Optional sections may be omitted. Just remove them or write None -->

<!-- ### Requirements -->
<!-- * Filling out the template is required. Any pull request that does not include enough information to be reviewed in a timely manner may be closed at the maintainers' discretion. -->
<!-- * All new code must have code coverage above 70% (https://docs.codecov.io/docs/about-code-coverage). -->
<!-- * CircleCI builds must be passed. -->
<!-- * Critical and blocker issues reported by Sorabot must be fixed. -->
<!-- * Branch must be rebased onto base branch (https://soramitsu.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/IS/pages/11173889/Rebase+and+merge+guide). -->


### Description of the Change

<!-- We must be able to understand the design of your change from this description. If we can't get a good idea of what the code will be doing from the description here, the pull request may be closed at the maintainers' discretion. -->
<!-- Keep in mind that the maintainer reviewing this PR may not be familiar with or have worked with the code here recently, so please walk us through the concepts. -->
This Pull Request introduces several changes to stateless validation:
1. FieldValidator now returns value of invalid field
2. Amount is checked to be greater than 0
3. CommandsValidator now appends counter to Command name, which allows understanding which command has failed.

The biggest change of this pull request is tests for FieldValidator, which are organized in a table-like manner with various test cases for different fields. Because of a lot of boilerplate, file is quite large, but it allows to add various test cases for different fields very easily.

### Benefits

1. Better error message for stateless validation
2. Test structure for FieldValidator allows us to test it easier

<!-- What benefits will be realized by the code change? -->

### Possible Drawbacks 

1. Size of the test file is quite large, and it may take some time to understand how it all works. 
<!-- What are the possible side-effects or negative impacts of the code change? -->
<!-- If no drawbacks, explicitly mention this (write None) -->

### Usage Examples or Tests *[optional]*

<!-- Point reviewers to the test, code example or documentation which shows usage example of this feature -->
If you want to add a new constraint to some field, you can test it by adding a test case to appropriate map in file field_validator_test.cpp.

### Alternate Designs *[optional]*
Google Test has parametrized test which allows running a test with different values however it would complicate code even, and require even more boilerplate code.
<!-- Explain what other alternates were considered and why the proposed version was selected -->

title: Release v1.0 alpha
body:
## What is this pull request?
This pull request brings v1.0 alpha release to public. 
   
## Why do you implement it? Why do we need this pull request?
It brings the following:

- client libraries for Java and Python, and any possible target language such as C#, Go, etc — check the page with [swig](http://www.swig.org) description
- ed25519 implementation from @Warchant repo, with many performance improvements and reliability — thanks to test cases from RFC, and swap of hashing algorithm with SHA3
- know-your-customer solution for account information. Check [API page](https://hyperledger.github.io/iroha-api/#set-account-detail) for more detail
- documentation updates, new contribution guidelines
- bug fixes and improvents 

  
## How to use the features provided in the pull request?
For each of listed you will find a test. Check them with `ctest .` in build folder.

## P.S. (optional)
Happy holidays and please report about any troubles to us using GitHub issues, telegram, rocketchat or Gitter.im!

title: Use static linking for ed25519 library
body:
## What is this pull request?
Ed25519 library is statically linked.
   
## Why do you implement it? Why do we need this pull request?
I've got a problem with new crypto library (I hope somebody else could also check it). Scenario is pretty simple:
1. Checkout actual develop branch.
2. Do clean.sh to ensure everything was cleaned.
3. Run cmake && make
This sequence gives me a stable problem when I try to run tests (or irohad, doesn't matter):
```
➜  build git:(develop) ctest
Test project /Users/konstantinmunichev/src/iroha/build
      Start  1: blob_converter_test
 1/77 Test  #1: blob_converter_test ....................   Passed    0.01 sec
      Start  2: block_insertion_test
 2/77 Test  #2: block_insertion_test ...................***Exception: Child aborted  0.01 sec
      Start  3: ametsuchi_test
 3/77 Test  #3: ametsuchi_test .........................***Exception: Child aborted  0.00 sec
.....
18% tests passed, 63 tests failed out of 77
```
The problem is ed25519 library (just an example):
```
➜  build git:(develop) test_bin/cache_test
dyld: Library not loaded: @rpath/libed25519.1.2.2.dylib
  Referenced from: /Users/konstantinmunichev/src/iroha/build/test_bin/cache_test
  Reason: image not found
```
The most interesting in this story is that rerunning build fixes the problem (e. g. touch CMakeLists.txt && make). Looks like shared lib wasn't created on the first passthrough but it actually did.

Looks like it should be fixed by setting rpath for this lib explicitly bit I tried and without success.

title: Sign everything with preliminary hashing
body:
## What is this pull request?
Signing and verifying objects with preliminary hashing.
   
## Why do you implement it? Why do we need this pull request?
Old model uses hashing while new one does not. We should do the same approach in both.
  
## How to use the features provided in the pull request?
```
import iroha

import time
import block_pb2
import endpoint_pb2_grpc
import grpc

txbuilder = iroha.ModelTransactionBuilder()
queryBuilder = iroha.ModelQueryBuilder()
crypto = iroha.ModelCrypto()
protoTxHelper = iroha.ModelProtoTransaction()
protoQueryHelper = iroha.ModelProtoQuery()

me_kp = crypto.convertFromExisting("227a458045f8d7d520907fb400461ae3c9101a68af2851d56a85b96fd791911a", "1011098aebf697597a59151a0ba1bb34bcf081f5195fa8de551b9a2b52be864613aae9771f35df7318e0d7b8571f043cd54581a0b1c5cf36fb05ac8956d291fe")

print(me_kp.publicKey().hex())

peer_kp = crypto.generateKeypair()
signatory_kp = crypto.generateKeypair()
account_kp = crypto.generateKeypair()
time = int(round(time.time() * 1000))
startCounter = 1
creator = "me@iroha"
signatory = "fyodor@iroha"


tx = txbuilder.creatorAccountId(creator)\
    .createdTime(time)\
    .createDomain("ru", "user").build()

tx_blob = protoTxHelper.signAndAddSignature(tx, me_kp).blob()

proto_tx = block_pb2.Transaction()
proto_tx.ParseFromString(''.join(map(chr, tx_blob)))

channel = grpc.insecure_channel('127.0.0.1:50051')
stub = endpoint_pb2_grpc.CommandServiceStub(channel)

stub.Torii(proto_tx)

print("done!")
```

title: Return vector in Blob::blob()
body:
## What is this pull request?
This pr is changes the iterface of `Blob::blob()` from `std::string` to `std::vector<uint8_t>`

## Why do you implement it? Why do we need this pull request?
There're issues with the swig string conversions, binary data is basically converted incorrectly


Also note, that this way is more or less bad in terms of efficiency (there's can be redundant copies in debug builds). I think it should be optimized: all binary data should be stored in the `std::vector<uint8_t>`. But that requires significant amount of work, so maybe there's some better approaches

title: Feature/apppend role check
body:
Thanks for the pull request!
Pull requests should have these details:

## What is this pull request?
This pull requests adds an additional check on Append Role Executor. It checks if assigner has enough permissions to give a certain role to assignee.

## Why do you implement it? Why do we need this pull request?
If assigner X has a set of permissions **A** and want to append role with set **B** of permissions to the user Y. 
This command must succeed if and only if **B** is a subset of **A**. This PR performs this check.

body:
This PR adds fixes related to integration of https://github.com/warchant/ed25519 library.

Users may install their own version of ed25519 and hash. 
Since different implementations are ABI-compatible, user is able to install the fastest implementation `amd64-64-24k` and use it, while other user (with armv7 arch, for example) can install different (portable ref10) implementation.

title: Feature/shared model bindings extend interface
body:
## What is this pull request?
Extending Swig interface with generating keypair based on provided seed string and using existing keypair.
   
## Why do you implement it? Why do we need this pull request?
These features are needed for Iroha lib clients.
  
## How to use the features provided in the pull request?
```
import iroha
crypto = iroha.ModelCrypto()
 # seed string length should be equal 32
kp_gen_test = crypto.generateKeypair("somerandomstring0123456789abcdef"); 
kp_test = crypto.convertFromExisting("227a458045f8d7d520907fb400461ae3c9101a68af2851d56a85b96fd791911a", "1011098aebf697597a59151a0ba1bb34bcf081f5195fa8de551b9a2b52be864613aae9771f35df7318e0d7b8571f043cd54581a0b1c5cf36fb05ac8956d291fe");
```
Same from Java. If provided keypair will not pass validation, exception will be thrown.

## Details/Features
- Extend Swig API with seed keypair generation
- Create convertFromExisting() method in ModelCrypto class
- Add static method to create Blobs from hex strings
- Add Blob argument constructors to key classes
- Add generate random string function
- Move some functions from types.hpp to byteutils.hpp

title: Add const specifier and remove duplication

## What is this pull request?
Small refactoring of sha3_hash, which removes some code duplication, and adds const where needed

title: Fix/shared model tx validation
body:
## What is this pull request?
Fixes stateless validation
   
## Why do you implement it? Why do we need this pull request?
This PR should fix stateless validation bug, which caused the following problem.

When we create CommandsValidator which validates tx, we invoke validate method, where we go through every command and call `boost::apply_visitor` using CommandsValidatorVisitor where for every possible command we have implemented operators to perform validation logic. Problem is that visitor wrongly deduces the command type which should be validated and invokes wrong operator. For example when we do `boost::apply_visitor` to AppendRole for some reason invokes RemoveSignatory operator, which is wrong.
The reason was found fixed: the order of commands in commands.proto should be the same as in variant template parameters
  
## How to use the features provided in the pull request?
Please check commands_validator_test

## Details/Features
Fixed order of commands in commands.proto

## Details/Features
- Add payload() abstract method into Signable
- Implement payload() in both Transaction and Query
- Use payload() call when signing instead of blob()
- Fix test according to changes above

title: [WIP] Merge of v0.95 preview-2 version in master branch

## What is this pull request?
This PR is a merge of new enhanced version, that was in development since previous version. 
   
This release brings following features: 
- Hot join of peer to the network
- Mac builds are checked in CI
- Increased number of transaction responses
- Separation of transport layer in between ordering gate and ordering service
- Sonarqube bot checking technical debt of the codebase
- Improved initialisation pipeline
- Fix of synchronisation service
- Effective implementation of cryptography: validation of payload signatures, signatures of block made by peer
- Improved representation of asset amount — now supports uint256
- RBAC permission model, supporting grant command
- Integration test for transaction pipeline, wide usage of mocks
- Implementation of block index storage, based on Redis
- Pagination for queries, which return wide range of transaction (GetTransactionHistory, etc.)
- Improved implementation of Yet Another Consensus
- Provisioning of the system via Ansible Playbook
- Builds of Iroha delivered in .deb, .rpm, .tar.gz, and soon brew for macOS
- Fixed build for ARMv7, macOS platform
- Several improvements in iroha-cli (C++ command-line interface)

title: Feature/tx mst handle
body:
In this PR TransactionProcessorImpl is able to handle multisignature transaction.

Some refactoring was done in c52c95c, there should be no (hopefully) logic changes. List of refactorings:
- Most of the types was moved out from mst_types to model ones
- Mst is fixed for using it's own type `DataType`, that basically an alias for `std::shared_ptr<iroha::model::Transaction>`
- In mst state is made an explicit copy of tx
- [tx_processor](https://github.com/hyperledger/iroha/pull/690/commits/c52c95cb42ecdd04e3f5bd3cd359e2f4aa8942b7#diff-2555aa1c75c15355ee489fce2274d681) code was shortened of boost (`join`, `for_each`, `adaptor::filtered`)
- also in [tx_processor](https://github.com/hyperledger/iroha/pull/690/commits/c52c95cb42ecdd04e3f5bd3cd359e2f4aa8942b7#diff-2555aa1c75c15355ee489fce2274d681) `TransactionResponse` is inlined, where it's possible

This also introduces a check of tx' [signatures](https://github.com/hyperledger/iroha/pull/690/files#diff-2555aa1c75c15355ee489fce2274d681R110), that also a good point for discussion

Note that it doesn't built due issue related FairMstProcessor problems usage (that's because of MstStorageStateImpl because of Peer, if you care). If you'd like to test you may build&run following targets:
- transaction_processor_test
- mst_processor_test
- maybe some other that I missed

title: Fix issue with duplicated txs return from GetAccountTransactions
body:
## What is this pull request?

Fix issue with duplicated txs return from GetAccountTransactions

## Why do you implement it? Why do we need this pull request?

In case of, there are two same user's transactions in a same block, GetAccountTransactions returns twice transactions.
In case of, there are three same user's transactions in a same block, GetAccountTransactions returns three times transactions.

For example:

If there are two same user's transactions, `getBlockIds( lrange username 0 -1 )` returns two same block ids.
ex.)
> 1) "1"
> 2) "1"

Thus, the number of transactions are 4.

If there are three same user's transactions, `getBlockIds( lrange username 0 -1 )` returns two same block ids.
ex.)
> 1) "1"
> 2) "1"
> 3) "1"

Thus, the number of transactions are 9.

I expected to be returned only one transaction. 

So I changed `std::vector<uint64_t> block_ids` in getBlockIds to `std::set<uint64_t> block_ids` to remove duplicated block ids.

## Details/Features
- Dedup block ids from getBlockIds method.

title: Feature/tx status
body:
## What is this pull request?
This pull request contains features to make possible inform about transaction status.
   
## Why do you implement it? Why do we need this pull request?
We need it for end users or anyone else informing - they did not have any ways to get status of a transaction they sent. Also now we check a blockstore if transaction not found in memory so we can get a status of transaction sent from another nodes.
  
## How to use the features provided in the pull request?
Now iroha-cli after it receives a transaction prints its hash which can be used to retrieve its status:
```
...
Command is formed. Choose what to do:
1. Add one more command to the transaction (add)
2. Send to Iroha peer (send)
3. Go back and start a new transaction (b)
4. Save as json file (save)
> : 2
Peer address: 127.0.0.1
Peer port: 50051
Congratulation, your transaction was accepted for processing.
Its hash is 18d3c453e0a84739d21f5dc073df04b245cf34eed5c811a3909c91efdefb496f
```
In the main menu users now have an option to retrieve transaction status:
```
Choose what to do:
1. New transaction (tx)
2. New query (qry)
3. New transaction status request (st)
> : 3
Choose action: 
1. Get status of transaction (get_tx_info)
0. Back (b)
> : 1
Requested tx hash: 18d3c453e0a84739d21f5dc073df04b245cf34eed5c811a3909c91efdefb496f
Tx hash is saved. Choose what to do:
1. Send to Iroha peer (send)
2. Save as json file (save)
0. Back (b)
> : 1
Peer address: 127.0.0.1
Peer port: 50051
**Transaction was successfully committed.**
```
## Details/Features
List of features / major commits
- Add possibility to get transaction status in iroha-cli
- Handler map from command service extracted into a separate cache entity
- Cache can contain a limited maximum amount of items; the oldest items are cleared automatically
- Perform a request to blockstore if cache is empty
- Add Redis index for transactions

Immutable model important part of Iroha development, because it may save models' invariants in runtime without violation.

title: Installation step for iroha
body:
This PR adds `package` step for iroha. On debian-based OS it will create `iroha-0.95.0-Linux.{tar.gz,deb}` packages.

Deb package has its own internal dependencies (like `libboost-system-dev`, etc) which should be installed manually using `apt`.

However, `libgrpc`, `libprotobuf` and `libgrpc++` can not be installed through apt, and I decided to package them together with binaries.

Currently, anything can be packaged (directory, file, library, binary, whatever) just by adding according `install` step, thanks to CPack.

Changelog:
- [x] tar.gz package
- [x] deb package
- [ ] MAC package (current version has some bundle code, but it is not tested by myself)
- [x] rpm bundle (untested)
- [x] ed25519 is now static lib
- [x] if some dependency is not installed, cmake now pretty prints what exactly is required with link to github and commit id.
- [x] added RPATH to this folders: `.` , `lib`, `../lib`. It means, that libraries can be in any of these directories.


Example:
```
# it will work only in Release now. Should it be changed?
$ cmake .. -DCMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=Release
$ make -j8 package

[100%] Built target tx_pipeline_integration_test
Run CPack packaging tool...
CPack: Create package using TGZ
CPack: Install projects
CPack: - Run preinstall target for: iroha
CPack: - Install project: iroha
CPack: Create package
CPack: - package: /home/bogdan/tools/iroha/build/iroha-0.95.0-Linux.tar.gz generated.
CPack: Create package using DEB
CPack: Install projects
CPack: - Run preinstall target for: iroha
CPack: - Install project: iroha
CPack: Create package
CPack: - package: /home/bogdan/tools/iroha/build/iroha-0.95.0-Linux.deb generated.

$ tar -xf /home/bogdan/tools/iroha/build/iroha-0.95.0-Linux.tar.gz
$ cd iroha-0.95.0-Linux
$ tree .
bogdan@xps:~/tools/iroha/build/iroha-0.95.0-Linux$ tree .
.
├── bin
│   ├── iroha-cli
│   └── irohad
└── lib
    ├── libgrpc++_reflection.so.1
    ├── libgrpc++.so.1
    ├── libgrpc.so.3
    └── libprotobuf.so.13
```

title: Fix tx creation from old commands, fix uint8 parsing
body:
Signed-off-by: kamilsa <kamilsa16@gmail.com>

## What is this pull request?
Fix bug in cli, which created tx from the old commands
   
## Why do you implement it? Why do we need this pull request?
1. i.e we create domain `ru`, then in next tx we want to create asset `dollar#ru`. It ends up with error of trying to run command create domain `ru` once again, because was sent 2nd time because of the bug in cli. This pr fixes this bug. 
2. Also there was a bug of parsing precision values from command line, which have type `uint8_t`. The problem is that it tries to put into `char` type, and then it parsed from `char` to `int`, and as result we get the wrong value. This pr fixes this bug.
  
## How to use the features provided in the pull request?
Now we can use cli without worrying about aforementioned bugs

## Details/Features
To solve issue with parsing `uint8_t` instead we parsed values as `uint32_t`.

title: Feature/crypto
body:
## What is this pull request?
Cryptography for Iroha - both for iroha-cli and irohad. Signing queries, blocks and transactions and their verification.
   
## Why do you implement it? Why do we need this pull request?
Cryptography is a key part of Iroha (and every other blockchain).
  
## How to use the features provided in the pull request?
From now every user and every node **must** have a keypair. We use ed25519, it could be generated by iroha-cli. For irohad:
`iroha@0409f90dfd31:/opt/iroha/build/bin$ ./irohad --config iroha.conf --genesis_block zero.block --keypair_name testnode`
And for iroha-cli:
`iroha@0409f90dfd31:/opt/iroha/build/bin$ ./iroha-cli --interactive --name admin@test --key_path keys/`
(assume we have files testnode.pub and testnode.priv in the same directory as irohad and admin@test.pub/priv in keys/).

## Details/Features
List of features / major commits
- signing of everything (queries, transactions, blocks)
- verification of every signature
- keys are absolutely necessary from now, you **can't** use Iroha without them
- crypto in yac
- genesis block is aware about crypto now
- crypto related bugfixes, test for them
- code refactoring

title: Add unsigned postgres checks for precision and transaction count
body:
## What is this pull request?
PR adds checks for PostgreSQL tables
   
## Why do you implement it? Why do we need this pull request?
To guarantee that in database we don't store negative integers
  
## P.S. (optional)
Since we don't have checks for underflow or overflow — this is useless and guarantees only datatype validity for data storage layer. We need to fix corresponding logic in business layer (model classes).

title: Feature/add redis indexing
body:
## What is this pull request?
Allows using redis to index blocks for fast querying account's  and account's assets transactions
   
## Why do you implement it? Why do we need this pull request?
So far to query account's transactions we went through the block and checked every transaction if it was created by this account. Applying redis indices we can speed up such queries, so that we don't need to go through every transaction in a block
  
## How to use the features provided in the pull request?
New block query class implements block query api, so that it is easy to plug in to current implementation

## Details/Features
During this PR new class RedisFlatBlockQuery was introduced, which inherits from FlatFileBlockQuery and overrides methods to get account's transactions and get account's assets transactions. There is no point to change methods to query blocks, so they were inherited from parent class without changes

title: Multi-plathome support based on hakodate branch
body:
This is based on the hakodate branch and is compatible with multiple platforms of cloud(Linux/amd64), Mac(Linux/Darwin), Raspberry Pi (Linux/armv7l). Just type “make" you can  build and run Hyperledger Iroha, and stop it, also execution of test, and run sample programs.

Specifically, it executes as follows. Run make using the git cloned Makefile in Hyperledger Iroha's directory. Internally, the following four steps are executed.

· Bulding of iroha-docker-develop container for development
· Building Hyperledger Iroha using by iroha-docker-develop container
· Extract binaries, libraries for execution from the built hyperledger Iroha
· Building a Hyperledger Iroha container for execution from the extracted binary, library

You can also start up with "make up", stop it with "make down". By running "make test" with Hyperledger Iroha running, you can running the test program in test_bin directory.

You can also execute sample programs which using iroha-cli by executing "make up" in the example directory, running Hyperledger Iroha, and typing "make hakodate". In this case, you can refer to the execution log with "make log".

In either case, if you want to stop Hyperledger Iroha do "make down".

Especially when using Raspberry Pi, swap is used about 3 GB at build time. Therefore, it is better to prepare 4 gigabytes or more of swap using external storage.

In this version, from the original docker-compose.yml, timing issues do not correspond to wait_for like doker official. If you can not connect by "make up" by timing problem, please try again "make up”.

I hope that this PR will be useful for Hyperledger Iroha.

title: Feature/refactor hakodate scripts

## What is this pull request?
1. In this PR hakodate scripts were refactored, so that we can set up IROHA_CLI environment variable to run iroha-cli from any place. Before we have hardcoded absolute path every time, when we called iroha-cli. 
2. It turns out that on mac port 10001 is not available. So it was changed to 10000. 
3. In order to everyone be able have their own config files, config.json was added to .gitignore and config.sample was created
   
## Why do you implement it? Why do we need this pull request?
To increase flexibility of running iroha example
  
## How to use the features provided in the pull request?
1. Now to add your own configs you need to copy config.sample file (like `cp config.sample config.json`) and edit config.json.
2. As before you can run hakodate.sh and run.sh. But now if you running iroha on your own machine and not in the docker you need to add environment variable `IROHA_CLI`, which points to iroha-cli binary

## Details/Features

Common functions for hakodate.sh and run.sh were moved to functions.sh file

title: Fix/hakodate
body:
## What is this pull request?
This PR contains hakodate presentation, which shows how to run iroha with live example. To make hakodate run, several bugs were fixed
   
## Why do you implement it? Why do we need this pull request?
We need to have example of running some simple scenario of working iroha.
  
## How to use the features provided in the pull request?
Run iroha. Go to example folder. Run hakodate.sh, press enter each time when you want to run next command or query

## Details/Features
Scenario which is executed in example is the following:

1. Create domain soramitsu
2. Create asset usd
3. Create users Alice and Bob
4. Add signatory to Bob
5. Add asset quantity to Alice: 200 usd
6. Add asset quantity to Alice: 100 usd
7. Send 1.80 usd from Alice to Bob

As result you can check that Alice has 198.20 usd and Bob has 101.80 usd.

Also in this PR the several bugs were fixed:

1. Wrong creation of Amount from string
2. Brand new user does not have permission to transfer money
3. Iroha-cli allowed creation of genesis block without list of peers
4. Iroha-cli created admin without rights to create user

title: feature/env-var-config
body:
- Add separate parameters for PostgreSQL
- Read peer number from env var
- Convert<V>::operator<T>() now uses emplace

## Why do you implement it? Why do we need this pull request?
Allows simpler deployment of docker instances by setting environment variables with `-e` instead of modifying docker image or creating a volume.
  
## How to use the features provided in the pull request?
Set environment variables before running `irohad`.
Example:
```
IROHA_BLOCK_STORE_PATH=$(pwd)/block_store IROHA_TORII_PORT=50051 IROHA_PG_HOST=localhost IROHA_PG_PORT=5432 IROHA_PG_USER=postgres IROHA_PG_PASS=mysecretpassword IROHA_REDIS_HOST=localhost IROHA_REDIS_PORT=6379 IROHA_PEER_NUMBER=0 ./cmake-build-debug/bin/irohad --genesis_block ./docs/zero.block
```

## Details/Features
- `IROHA_BLOCK_STORE_PATH` - path to block store
- `IROHA_TORII_PORT` - port for client interaction
- `IROHA_PG_HOST`, `IROHA_PG_PORT`, `IROHA_PG_USER`, `IROHA_PG_PASS` - PostgreSQL connection details
- `IROHA_REDIS_HOST`, `IROHA_REDIS_PORT` - Redis connection details
- `IROHA_PEER_NUMBER` - number of current peer from list of peers in genesis block

title: Feature/hakodate
body:
## What is this pull request?

Build IROHA with makefile. You can build IROHA using make target and create and execute a docker image. Currently, the following target is prepared.

```
# - all (default) - buid iroha-build container, and build iroha
# - docker - build iroha runtime container
# - docker-test - build iroha runtime and test container
# - up - running iroha container by docker-compose
# - down - stop and remove iroha container by docker-compose
# - test-up - running iroha-test container buy docker-compose
# - test - down - stop and remove iroha - test container by docker - compose
# - test - exec all test commands
# - clean - cleaning protobuf schemas and build directory
```

In the target test, the commands created in test_bin are executed in alphabetical order.
  
## Why do you implement it? Why do we need this pull request?

It is to make IROHA easy to build and run for testing.
  
## How to use the features provided in the pull request?

With make alone, create an iroha-docker-develop container, build iroha, and create a docker image of IROHA for execution.
By executing make up, IROHA's docker container is started using docker-compose. You can stop and delete the docker container of IROHA started up by make down.

## Details/Features

Add Makefile and some scripts under scripts directory.

## Additional dependencies (optional)

## P.S. (optional)

title: Feature/test ir341
body:
## What is this pull request?
Changes related to crypto:
- hash provider removed from everywhere
- crypto reworked (hashes and signatures)
- everything uses crypto were changed accordingly
- changed model for proto - transaction and query: both of them now have a payload field contained all the data and signature field for a payload's signature
- all code is changed according to new model (serializers, deserializers, converters and some other)

Other changes:
- cmake proto compilation improvements
- queries in serializers are const now
- std::abs compilation issue (again!)
   
## Why do you implement it? Why do we need this pull request?
Now to use crypto functions you have to serialize your model object to proto object and use its string representation (see code example below). This way allows us to get consistent hashes/signatures which do not depend from target platform internal binary data representation (endianess and so on). Proto model changes simplify crypto usage: now you always have a payload field and hashes/signs are calculated from it.
  
## How to use the features provided in the pull request?
Typical workflow for hashing and signing now:
```
protocol::Transaction tx;
hash256_t hash = sha3_256(tx.payload().SerializeAsString());
iroha::sign(hash.to_string(), pubkey, privkey);
```

To get a signature from string there is from_string function available:
```
Signature sign{};
sign.pubkey = pubkey_t::from_string(pubkey_string);
sign.signature = sig_t::from_string(signature_string);
```

title: Fix/dev environment
body:
This PR provides fixes useful for remote development:
- Change docker container username to `iroha`, since host username can contain symbols considered bad by `adduser`.
- Change project name from `iroha` to `iroha${UID}`, so that multiple users can safely share docker daemon

### How to sync remote development environment
- Sync directly from your PC
`rsync -azP /path/to/local/iroha username@remote-host:/path/to/remote/iroha`
- Sync from remote docker. Reverse SSH is required to be running. Check the IP network in docker using `ip addr show`.
`ssh username@remote-host-docker-ip 'rsync -e "ssh -p 10000" -azP username@localhost:/path/to/local/iroha /path/to/remote/iroha'`
where `-azP` stands for archive, compress, and allow partial transfers, and `10000` is reverse SSH port

title: Fix genesis block generator yielding different blocks due to timestamp
body:
`swarm-deploy.sh` used block generator for genesis block. Since nodes are deployed sequentially, timestamps of genesis blocks were different, which resulted in different genesis block hash.

This PR fixes the creation timestamp of genesis block to 0.

title: Add test, which calculates hashes from different proto objects and compares them
body:
## What is this pull request?
New test for proto is added. It creates 8 proto objects in a different ways, but filled with the same data.  Then, every object is serialized and hashed.

Then hashes are compared with each other. If they are equal, it means that protobuf is deterministic library, which can be used for signing.


Also I added sha3_256/512 functions which calculate hash of `std::string`

title: Fix signatory bugs in develop
body:
## What is this pull request?
Fix AddSignatory / RemoveSignatory command's bug.

## Why do you implement it? Why do we need this pull request?

iroha has following bugs.

## 1. AddSignatory bug.

### What is this issue?

If you want to add signatory to a user, iroha causes following postgres error.
    > insert or update on table "account_has_signatory" violates foreign key constraint "account_has_signatory_public_key_fkey".
Because not inserted to signatory table before insertion to account_has_signatory table.

### How resolved?

I inserted insertSignatory method before insertAccountSignatory method.

## 2. RemoveSignatory bug.

### What is this issue?

If you want to remove a signatory from a user, but the signatory remains in signatory table.
Because not deleted the signatory from signatory table after deletion from account_has_signatory table.

### How resolved?

I added deleteSignatory method and inserted the method after deleteAccountSignatory method.

title: Docker swarm deploy script using docker-machine
body:
- Use docker-machine to connect to remote docker daemon
- Use swarm overlay network for peer communication
- Manually deploy docker-compose on each node

## How to use the features provided in the pull request?
- Set up SSH connections with machines using public key (e.g. use `ssh-keygen` to generate keypair, and transfer `.pub` file to machines)
- Install `docker-machine`
- For each machine, run
```bash
docker-machine create \
  --driver generic \
  --generic-ip-address=127.0.0.1 \ # machine IP address
  --generic-ssh-key ~/.ssh/id_rsa \ # path to private key used with SSH
  --generic-ssh-user username \ # user specified in key
  your-unique-machine-name
```
This command will set up docker daemon on each machine
- Set up docker swarm on specified machines by running `docker swarm init` on one of the machines. Other machines should join the swarm as managers in order to overlay network being extended on creation.

title: Merge v0.95 preview codebase
body:
## What is this pull request?
v0.95 preview release

Version 0.95 preview brings following highlights:

- YAC Consensus
- Observable-based interaction
- Transport agnostic architecture design
- Permission system for transactions and queries
- Separate validation stages: stateless, stateful, chain
   

## How to use the features provided in the pull request?
### Preconditions
Docker installed

### Running the system

<https://github.com/hyperledger/iroha/wiki/How-to-start-Iroha>  <https://github.com/hyperledger/iroha/wiki/How-to-use-Iroha-client>

## Details/Features
### New commands

- add asset
- add peer
- add signatory
- assign master key
- create asset
- create account
- create domain
- remove signatory
- set account permissions
- set account quorum
- transfer asset

### New queries

- get account
- get signatories
- get account transactions
- get account asset transactions
- get account assets

### Known issues

- No valid cryptography
- No recovery after critical errors
- Consensus guarantee only CFT   
- No block loader

title: Feature/yac
body:
## What is this pull request?
This pr provides adding functionality of distributed consensus algorithm called "YAC".
Yac is BFT algorithm based on voting. [Base paper](https://www.overleaf.com/read/wzhwjzbjvrzn) provide details.
   
## Why do you implement it? Why do we need this pull request?
We need consensus algorithm to distribute and agree on data in cluster.
  
## How to use the features provided in the pull request?
 - Do you provide tests, or use case examples?
Tests are provided in test/module/irohad/consensus/yac folder. Each dependency component is covered by unit tests. Different yac working scenarios are present in _cold case_ and _sunny day_ tests.
PR, also, contains integration test for algorithm: iroha_root/integration/consensus. Build test and execute many instances of it for making one round on consensus. Usage: `./consensus_sunny_day 5 3`, where 5 means number of instances, 3 number of current instance.

- Describe how to use features in your pull request.
Yac is fully compatible with current Iroha architecture.  From the perspective of other modules of the architecture, YAC (whole module) is a _ConsensusGate_ component.

## Details/Features
Features of implementation:
- Transport agnostic
- Clear division of module responsibilities
- All dependencies are interfaces
- All components covered by tests

Minuses of implementation:
- Ordering doesn't depend on hash 
- Absence of effective realization of crypto provider
- Only normal case is provided
- Implementation doesn't use modern concurrency techniques for working

Architecture issues:
- _YacGate_ is implementation of _ConsensusGate_.
- Yac by its nature doesn't operate with block objects. Consensus operate wtih hash values, thus, commit and vote made in terms of hashes. Yac interface for it called _HashGate_.
- The algorithm of consensus provided in yac.hpp. Algorithm manage internal storage and network for concluding own decisions. 
- The network is provided in yac_network_interface.hpp. Current network implementation is grpc.
- Ordering of current consensus round is provided in cluster_order.hpp.
- PeerOrderer interface is responsible for retrieving information about peers and creating order on it for each round. This module similar to peer service, but in current Yac we don't use trust system, therefore, the module requires only peers stored in the ledger.
- Yac_crypto_provider.hpp presents cryptography for business objects: votes, commits, rejects.

## P.S.
How to review? I think good strategy get acquainted with all interfaces and business objects in irohad/consensus/yac/ folder. Next, go to the algorithm itself in impl/yac.cpp, after look for tests in _yac_sunny_day_test.cpp_ file. Similarly with all other dependencies.

## P.P.S.
Whole transaction pipeline for Yac depends on ordering service. Current implementation of OS presented in #476.  But good point is implementation totally independent from it.

title: Feature/concurrent ordering service
body:
## What is this pull request?
OrderingGate and OrderingService implementation using gRPC and TBB `concurrent_queue`.
  
## How to use the features provided in the pull request?
- Start ordering service on one node
- Start ordering gate on all nodes, and point it to node with ordering service
- Send transactions to ordering service using `propagate_transaction`, and listen to proposals with `on_proposal` method of ordering gate.

## Details/Features
- Ordering service emits proposals on two events: when timer is up and queue is not empty, and when transaction is received and queue contains sufficient number of transactions

## Additional dependencies
- Threading Building Blocks - concurrent queue

title: Feature/torii iroha integration
body:
## What is this pull request?
Torii now is connected to other iroha module - specifically query and transaction processor. 
   
## Why do you implement it? Why do we need this pull request?
CommandService uses transaction processor that handles transactions (validates and sends to OS). Now response is related only to Stateless validation status. 
QueryService uses query processor to handle queries (validate and execute). 

To send from transport specific message (protobuf) to iroha model Pb-..-Factory is used.  

## How to use the features provided in the pull request?
2 tests are presented in torii - for commands and queries.

title: Feature/simulator
body:
## What is this pull request?
Implementation of simulator using Block_Creator and Verified_Proposal_Creator interfaces.
   
## Why do you implement it? Why do we need this pull request?
Simulator is a method used to create vote for Consensus. Simulator uses stateful validator to verify proposal and create Block for voting.
  

## How to use the features provided in the pull request?
Simulator will generate event `on_block` after each call of process_proposal. 
Note: Simulator can return `nullopt,` in this case node knows that it is faulty and intentionally do not generate wrong Block. Simulator will ask local `Ametsuchi` last block and if the height of the proposal is not consistent with the last block it will return generate `nullopt` Block. 

Test is provided in `simulator_test.`

## Details/Features
List of features / major commits
- Now proposal has height
- Add optional to events on_block, on_verified_proposal 
-  Implement simulator
- Implement simulator test for common case

title: Add a Codacy badge to README.md
Merge develop to master branch
body:
Update master branch with current develop.
Feature list:   

- New concepts:
        * Pluggable consensus
        * Observable-based interaction
        * Less coupled components
        * Transport agnostic
        * Permission system for transactions and queries
        * Separate validation stages: stateless, stateful, chain

 - New architecture:
        * Clear transaction and query pipeline
        * Each component follows single responsibility principle of SOLID
        * Using async data approach with reactive extensions
        * All major components are interface-based
        * No singletons: all dependencies are passed with constructor
        * Storage has temporary and mutable views for validations and commits
        * Independent data layer

- Testing:
        * Active use of unit tests and improved quality metric (statement coverage > 90%)
        * Dependencies are easily mocked for testing

- Ametsuchi:
        * Storage is a module of iroha
        * PostgreSQL is used for world state view
        * Each block stored in own file, in pretty readable JSON format

## Why do you implement it? Why do we need this pull request?
Synchronizer is a module needed to process commit messages from consensus gate. Synchronizer will use Chain Validation to validate and apply block to ledger. If it fails to apply commit synchronizer will use BlockLoader to download all missed blocks.  
  
## How to use the features provided in the pull request?
We provide test  here on good case here: https://github.com/hyperledger/iroha/blob/feature/synchronizator-new/test/module/irohad/synchronizer/synchronizer_test.cpp

title: [Ready] Peer service
body:
## What is this pull request?
This is simple implementation of asynchronous peer service.
   
## Why do you implement it? Why do we need this pull request?
It is able to answer the following questions:
- what peers are currently online
- what is their state (state is `<merkle root, height>`)
- what is the latest state among all peers

It DOES NOT answer the questions:
- who is the leader
- what is the current order
- who is the proxy tail
These are consensus-specific things and will be implemented in consensus module. From peer service we need only availability and peer's state.
  
## How to use the features provided in the pull request?
There is an example in:
`iroha/test/module/irohad/peerservice/peerservice_peer`

1. go to build directory
2. `cmake ..`
3. `make peerservice_peer`
4. `cd test_bin`
5. ```
    peerservice_peer 4 0
    peerservice_peer 4 1
    peerservice_peer 4 2
    peerservice_peer 4 3
    ```

*Peer service is an implementation of GRPC server, it MUST be registered in grpc::ServerBuilder*.

## Additional dependencies (optional)
`lookup3.c`

# How  to make it better?
- add logger
- handle exception cases 
- validate heartbeats (hash lengths, pubkey lengths, etc) 
- add unit tests

body:

## How to use the features provided in the pull request?
`PeerCommunicationService` propagates transaction with `propagate_transaction` method of `OrderingService`, receives a proposal by listening to `on_proposal`. It then does stateful validation, forms a block, which is voted for with `vote_block` method of `ConsensusService`. Then, a commit message is received by listening to `on_commit`, and chain validation is performed.

title: Feature/stateful validation stub
body:
## What is this pull request?
Provide backbone for stateful validation
     
## How to use the features provided in the pull request?
For adding new commands for performing you should extend class `CommandValidatorStub` with your type and assign it method to hadler map. Usage of validation perform only via `validate(const Command&)` method. This happens because hander map provide parameter polymorphic behaviour.

## Additional dependencies
This PR coupled with [andrey's pull request](https://github.com/hyperledger/iroha/pull/401). I use parameter polymorphic library provided by andrey.
Another coupled PR is [ametsuchi stubs](https://github.com/hyperledger/iroha/pull/402). I totally recommend check this request first before this one

title: Fix error about ambiguous abs(double) in peer_service
body:
I got the following error when building iroha.

```
In file included from /home/debian/workspace/iroha/irohad/peer_service/monitor.hpp:19:0,
                 from /home/debian/workspace/iroha/irohad/peer_service/monitor.cpp:17:
/home/debian/workspace/iroha/irohad/peer_service/peer_service.hpp: In member function 'bool peer_service::Node::operator>(const peer_service::Node&) const':
/home/debian/workspace/iroha/irohad/peer_service/peer_service.hpp:81:44: error: call of overloaded 'abs(double)' is ambiguous
       return (std::abs(trust_ - node.trust_) < -1e5) ? created_ < node.created_
```

This PR makes fix it.

title: Feature/block synchronizer
body:
This brunch propose new type of validation called chain validation.

Chain validation - validation of blocks on commit phase of consensus.
On commit phase, when peer's hash not matched to commit hash peer need load blocks from other peers who voted for it. One of possible situations is loading more than one block. For verify all received blocks we apply chain validation. This means that we statefully check signatures of each block, verify previous hash and height of block. For processing chain validation we propose "ChainValidator" class that use mutable ametsuchi state for verification.

title: Feature/fb exceptions
body:
- Introduce `Expected<T>` similar to [ptal/expected](https://github.com/ptal/expected), but not using boost.

- How to use: https://github.com/hyperledger/iroha/blob/develop/test/module/expected/expected_test.cpp

- `Expected<T>` helps:
  - We can assume functions that returns this type may have invalid value.
  - We cannot forget to catch exceptions.

- Each exception should derive:
  - `exception::Critical`
    - Let users to report this bug.
  - `exception::WontFix
  - `exception::HelpWanted`
    - Currently, it is for `exception::NotImplementedException`
  - `exception::ConfigError` (some more clear name?)
    - It is due to mistake of user input.
If any other types are needed, please tell me.

## Changelog:
- there is no need in installing grpc in that image, because circle 2.0 runs build in `warchantua/iroha-dev` image. I installed all required dependencies there, including grpc.
- removed unnecessary ubuntu image 
- added sonarqube and cppcheck analyzers. Reports automatically parsed and pushed to https://sonar.innoctf.com (you can be authorized via github). I own domain innoctf.com only, I hope @takemiyamakoto will create A record for `sonar.soramitsu.co.jp` and receive a certificate (https is mandatory!) for this domain. P.S.: you can do it via `letsencrypt`.

## Future work:
- Soon I will add `valgrind` analyzer for iroha-main and other binaries (+all tests). Its results will be displayed in sonarqube interface. It looks really nice there :)

title: Feature/re construct
body:
This archtecture 
```
core/
  ┣━ config    // config loader
  ┣━ consensus // sumeragi
  ┣━ cryptos   // sha3 / ed25519, (RSA?) and so on
  ┣━ utils     // datetime / random / exception / logger 
  ┣━ membership_service // view change / add peer
  ┣━ chaincode // chaoncode machine (parser?, lxc?)
  ┣━ runtime   // it had be called executor before. What is best name?
  ┃   ┣━ permission // permission validator
  ┃   ┗━ command    // operate some commands
  ┣━ connection // grpc / (HTTP server?) 
  ┗━ infra     // it contains implements what depend on other library. 
      ┣━ config // loader with json.
      ┣━ crypto // sha3 with keccak lib / ed25519 with orlp
      ┗━ utils  // logger with spdlog
include/generated // flatbuffers generated file      
flatbuffers/    // flatbuffers scheme      
```

title: Migrating to Circle 2.0
body:
### Introducing `tiny` 

tiny - is a minimal docker image, which includes **only** iroha binaries compiled in Release mode, config files and libraries.
It can be built by calling `docker/build.sh` in one minute.

As a consequence, we do not create isolated environment to build iroha image (iroha-dev), so *to build tiny you should be able to build iroha in your OS*.

But this environment was saved as `warchantua/iroha-dev` and used in circle 2.0 to speed-up the build process.

### Config-discovery was removed

It means, that you **can not** create a network with docker-compose (it was also removed). 

BUT, with use of peer service, I can write new docker-compose file, which will be able to:
 - create arbitrary number of nodes connected in a network
 - deploy this stack on a docker swarm in one command

(docker dev team has released docker-compose v3.0 and this is possible now!)

### Circle 2.0

Now circle 2.0 builds and pushes to docker hub successful builds from *any branch*.
To access your image:
```
docker pull hyperledger/iroha-docker:branch_name
```

And then use. 
List of all releases is on docker hub: https://hub.docker.com/r/hyperledger/iroha-docker/tags/

title: Hotfix/test peer service
body:
I fixed compile errors. Main problem was as below:
```
/opt/iroha/tools/issue_transaction.cpp:44:27: error: expected unqualified-id before numeric constant
         const std::string DOMAIN = "domain";
                           ^
```
This is due to GCC standard library `math.h` in `cmath`.
```
$ cat /usr/include/math.h | grep DOMAIN
# define DOMAIN		1
```
The detail is here: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/31751723/math-h-macro-collisions

To solve this problem, I added prefix 'k' to constants variables. please modify as you think proper, if you don't think it's appropriate.

Another issues I fixed as follows:
- some linker errors
- incorrect include guards in `peer_service.hpp`, `config_format.hpp`(sorry, this is my mistake.)
- add `std::` namespace in `issue_transaction.cpp` (this avoids invoking compile-error)

title: Hotfix/smart contract
body:
I found bug in attaching Asset to Account. This PR is for solving it. Protobuf outputs below error:
```
[libprotobuf ERROR google/protobuf/wire_format_lite.cc:534] String field 'Api.Account.assets' contains invalid UTF-8 data when parsing a protocol buffer. Use the 'bytes' type if you intend to send raw bytes.
```
It cannot be detected by a current test, *java_query_repo_account_test*. It is detected in *smart_contract/instances/sample_rating/WeightedRateAttach.java*.

Don't merge this PR until its problem is solved, please.

title: Feature/api
body:
- Implemet Java <-> C++ accessing levelDB repository.
  - Java can add/update/remove Account, Asset, SimpleAsset, Domain, Peer.
    - For exchanging data between C++ and Java, HashMap<String, String>(Java) and std::map<std::string, std::string>(C++) are used.
    - Each objects (Account, Asset and so on) are constructed as JSON like structures, so exchanging data by using hash map is heavy work. I think exchanging data by using JSON string is better.

- Use fPIC compile options because shared library is used for Java to use Iroha native code.
  - SET(CMAKE_CXX_FLAGS "-g -std=c++1y -Wall -fPIC")
  - If this PR is merged, be aware of libhash.a compile error message. Local environment might show 'recompile with -fPIC'.

- By invoking JVM, valgrind detects a lot of memory leaks. I don't know whether it comes from Java or C++.

title: Feature/data model tx
body:
- Transaction Builder (gRPC version)
- How to:

```cpp
#include <transaction_builder/transaction_builder.hpp>

using transaction::TransactionBuilder;
using type_signatures::Add;
using type_signatures::Domain;

Api::Domain domain;
domain.set_ownerpublickey("pubkey1");
domain.set_name("name");
```
- Then, if you'd like to build Add, Remove, Update:
```cpp
auto txDomain = TransactionBuilder<Add<Domain>>()
  .setSenderPublicKey("public key")
  .setDomain(domain)
  .build();
```
- If you'd like to build Transfer:
```cpp
auto txDomain = TransactionBuilder<Transfer<Domain>>()
  .setSenderPublicKey("public key")
  .setReceiverPublicKey("receiver pubkey")
  .setDomain(domain)
  .build();
```
- more detail usage:
  - https://github.com/hyperledger/iroha/blob/feature/data-model-tx/test/transaction_builder/transaction_builder_add_test.cpp
  - https://github.com/hyperledger/iroha/blob/feature/data-model-tx/test/transaction_builder/transaction_builder_transfer_test.cpp

- Note:
  - I think it is hard for this builder user to use google protobuf class like this:
    - https://github.com/hyperledger/iroha/blob/feature/data-model-tx/test/transaction_builder/transaction_builder_transfer_test.cpp#L105-L106
  - Helper function of creating objects should be implemented, I think.

title: Feature/transaction builder
Feature/transaction builder
body:
- Transaction builder
  - Create Currency(SimpleAsset), Asset, Domain, Account, Message and Peer.
- Usage
```cpp
auto domain = TransactionBuilder<object::Domain>()
  .setOwnerPublicKey(ownerPublicKey)
  .setName(name)
  .build();
```
- If too few elements are set, UnsetBuildArgmentsException will be thrown.
- Currently, the number of required elements is fixed. e.g. TransactionBuilder<object::Domain>() requires two elements, ownerPublicKey and name.

- Implemented

- Pending

title: Task/sumeragi json format error
body:
- Sorry, I can't solve circle-ci error `docker run -p 1204:1204 hyperledger/iroha-docker /test.sh`

- Created sumeragi.json format checker
    - It ensures valid nested json keys, values and types of values of sumeragi.json.
    - Example
        - `ensureKeyValueFormat<ValueType>(jsonObject, {"hoge", "foo", "fuga"}, 0)` verifies the format of json `{"hoge":{"foo":{"fuga":"value"}}}`
        - `{"me":{"iP": "172.17.0.4", ...}}` can be detected and it shows warning `Type mismatch "ip" in "me"`
        - `{"me":{"ip": "172.17.0.999", ...}}` can be detected and it shows warning of invalid IP addr message.
    - Not implemented
        - find keys that sumeragi.json does not use.
            - e.g. In sumeragi.json, text including `{"uselessKey","12345"}` cannot be detected.
        - verify whether valid base64 encoded string (publicKey) or not.
